Conversations.Prompt: so are both the workflows independent or will run one after the another
Conversations.Answer: The workflows defined in a GitHub Actions configuration file are independent of each other by default. They will run in parallel and not wait for each other to complete. If you want them to run sequentially, you can define a dependency between the workflows using the workflow_run event.In your case, if you want the "Lint and Format Backend" workflow to run before the "Lint and Format Frontend" workflow, you can use the workflow_run event to trigger the latter workflow when the former completes. Here's an example of how you can modify the workflow files to achieve this:Backend Workflow (backend-lint-format.yml):[CODE_BLOCK_0]Frontend Workflow (frontend-lint-format.yml):[CODE_BLOCK_1]In the frontend workflow, the workflow_run event is used to trigger the workflow when the "Lint and Format Backend" workflow completes. The needs keyword is used to specify that the frontend workflow depends on the backend workflow.This setup ensures that the frontend workflow will run only after the backend workflow has completed.

Conversations.Answer: The end result of the workflow you've configured is to automatically run linting and formatting checks on both the frontend and backend components of your project whenever a push is made to the main branch.Here's what each job in the workflow does:Lint and Format Frontend Job:This job runs on an Ubuntu environment.It checks out the code from the repository.Sets up Node.js and installs frontend dependencies.Runs ESLint to perform linting checks on the frontend code.Runs Prettier to format the frontend code.If any of the linting or formatting checks fail, the job will also fail.Lint and Format Backend Job:This job runs on an Ubuntu environment.It checks out the code from the repository.Sets up Python and installs Flake8 and Black.Runs Flake8 to perform linting checks on the backend Python code.Runs Black in check mode to ensure the backend code is properly formatted.If any of the linting or formatting checks fail, the job will also fail.Overall, if all the checks for both frontend and backend pass without errors, the workflow run will be considered successful. If any of the checks fail, the workflow run will be marked as failed, and you'll be able to see the specific errors in the workflow run details on GitHub. This helps you ensure that the codebase meets the linting and formatting standards you've defined for both frontend and backend components.

Conversations.Answer: I see, you want the workflow to not only perform linting and formatting checks but also automatically apply formatting changes and merge to the main branch if the checks pass. Here's how you can modify your workflow to achieve that:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Please note that automatically pushing to and merging into the main branch can have significant consequences. It's recommended to use this approach with caution and consider implementing additional safeguards, such as requiring pull request reviews or running extensive tests before merging.This workflow will perform the following steps:Check out the code and set up Node.js.Install frontend dependencies and run ESLint for linting and Prettier for formatting.If the checks pass, it commits the formatting changes to a new branch (you might want to change this behavior to suit your needs).It pushes the changes to the remote repository.It checks out the main branch and merges the changes from the newly created branch.It pushes the merged changes to the main branch.Remember to adapt this workflow to your specific needs and consider using it with caution, especially when automatically pushing and merging code.

ListOfCode.Content:
name: Autoformat and Merge

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  autoformat-and-merge:
    name: Autoformat and Merge
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Node.js
        uses: actions/setup-node@v2
        with:
          node-version: '14'

      - name: Install frontend dependencies
        run: npm install --prefix frontend

      - name: Lint with ESLint
        run: npm run lint --prefix frontend

      - name: Format with Prettier
        run: npm run format --prefix frontend

      - name: Commit changes
        run: |
          git config user.email "actions@github.com"
          git config user.name "GitHub Actions"
          git add frontend
          git commit -m "Autoformat frontend code"
          git push

      - name: Merge to main
        run: |
          git checkout main
          git merge ${{ github.sha }}
          git push origin main

Also, keep in mind that automatically merging pull requests and pushing code to the main branch can have significant implications. ListOfCode.Content:
name: Autoformat and Merge

on:
  pull_request:
    types:
      - closed

jobs:
  autoformat-and-merge:
    name: Autoformat and Merge
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Check PR status
        id: check_pr_status
        uses: actions/github-script@v5
        with:
          github-token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          script: |
            const pr = await github.pulls.get({
              owner: context.repo.owner,
              repo: context.repo.repo,
              pull_number: context.payload.pull_request.number
            });
            return pr.data.merged;

      - name: Checkout code
        if: steps.check_pr_status.outputs.result == 'true'
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      # Rest of the steps for linting, formatting, committing, and merging...

name: Lint and Format

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  lint-format-frontend:
    name: Lint and Format Frontend
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Node.js
        uses: actions/setup-node@v2
        with:
          node-version: '14'

      - name: Install frontend dependencies
        run: npm install --prefix frontend

      - name: Lint with ESLint
        run: npm run lint --prefix frontend

      - name: Format with Prettier
        run: npm run format --prefix frontend || echo 'Formatting check failed, but continuing'

  lint-format-backend:
    name: Lint and Format Backend
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v2
        with:
          python-version: '3.x'

      - name: Install backend dependencies
        run: pip install flake8 black

      - name: Lint with Flake8
        run: flake8 backend

      - name: Format with Black
        run: black backend --check || echo 'Formatting check failed, but continuing'

Conversations.Prompt: is it a good practice to separate different github action workflows in dirs
Conversations.Answer: Yes, it can be a good practice to organize different GitHub Actions workflows into separate directories, especially when you have multiple workflows for different parts of your project or for different purposes. Organizing workflows in directories can help keep your repository's root directory clean and make it easier to locate specific workflows when needed.Here are some benefits of organizing workflows into separate directories:Clarity: Each workflow's purpose is clear from the directory name, making it easier for contributors to understand the purpose of each workflow.Modularity: Workflows for different parts of the project can be managed and updated independently, reducing the chances of conflicts or unexpected interactions between workflows.Ease of Maintenance: When workflows are grouped together based on their related tasks, it's easier to make changes or updates to a specific set of workflows.Readability: With separate directories, you can include additional documentation, configuration files, or other resources specific to each set of workflows, enhancing readability and organization.Scalability: As your project grows, having separate directories for workflows makes it easier to manage and maintain a larger number of workflows.For example, you might organize your workflows like this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this structure, each directory contains workflows related to a specific set of tasks (linting and formatting, deployment, etc.), making it easy to manage and understand the purpose of each workflow.Ultimately, the organization should align with your project's needs and the complexity of your workflows. It's important to strike a balance between organization and simplicity, ensuring that contributors can easily locate and understand the workflows while avoiding excessive complexity.

Conversations.Prompt: what does codeql analysis do?
Conversations.Answer: CodeQL analysis is a static code analysis tool provided by GitHub that helps identify and prevent security vulnerabilities in your codebase. It goes beyond traditional static analysis by allowing you to write custom queries to analyze your code for security vulnerabilities, data leaks, and other code quality issues. CodeQL is capable of analyzing a wide variety of programming languages and can help you find security vulnerabilities such as:Code Vulnerabilities: CodeQL can help identify known vulnerabilities in third-party libraries or components that you might be using in your project.Data Leaks: It can detect code that might unintentionally expose sensitive information or data.Code Quality Issues: CodeQL can find coding patterns that could lead to bugs or security vulnerabilities, such as unhandled exceptions or potential null pointer dereferences.Security Misconfigurations: It can detect misconfigurations or issues in security-sensitive areas of your code, like authentication and authorization.Taint Analysis: CodeQL can track how potentially tainted data (e.g., user inputs) flows through your code, helping you identify places where it might be misused or where injections might occur.The power of CodeQL comes from its query language, which allows you to express complex patterns of code behavior to identify potential issues. You can also benefit from the CodeQL community, which shares queries and best practices for detecting specific types of vulnerabilities.CodeQL can be integrated into your GitHub repository's workflow using GitHub Actions, allowing you to automatically run CodeQL analysis whenever code changes are pushed to your repository. This helps in catching security vulnerabilities early in the development process and maintaining a more secure codebase.Keep in mind that CodeQL analysis does have a learning curve, especially when writing custom queries. However, it can significantly enhance the security of your software projects by identifying security vulnerabilities and code quality issues that might not be easily caught through manual code review.

Conversations.Prompt: how I implement this for the above project
Conversations.Answer: To implement CodeQL analysis for your project, you'll need to set up a GitHub Actions workflow that runs CodeQL analysis on your codebase. Here's a step-by-step guide on how to do it for your project:Set Up CodeQL Analysis Workflow:Create a new file named .github/workflows/codeql-analysis.yml in the root of your repository. This file will define the GitHub Actions workflow for CodeQL analysis.Configure Workflow:Add the following content to the codeql-analysis.yml file:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Commit and Push:Commit the codeql-analysis.yml file and push it to your GitHub repository. This will trigger the GitHub Actions workflow whenever code is pushed to the main branch.Run CodeQL Analysis:GitHub Actions will automatically run CodeQL analysis whenever there are code changes in the main branch. You can monitor the progress and results in the "Actions" tab of your GitHub repository.Keep in mind that this basic setup will perform general CodeQL analysis on your codebase to identify potential vulnerabilities and code quality issues. CodeQL analysis is highly customizable, allowing you to write your own custom queries to target specific security concerns relevant to your project.To further customize and extend CodeQL analysis for your project, you can:Define custom queries to address specific security concerns in your project.Configure CodeQL scanning for additional branches, not just main.Use CodeQL's query packs to focus on specific security topics.Integrate the analysis results with GitHub Security Alerts and Code Scanning features.Please note that CodeQL analysis is a powerful tool, but it might require some time and effort to fine-tune and adjust the analysis results to suit your project's specific needs.

ListOfCode.Content:
name: CodeQL Analysis

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  analyze:
    name: Analyze code with CodeQL
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Initialize CodeQL
        uses: github/codeql-action/init@v1

      - name: Autobuild

      - name: Analyze

on:
  push:
    branches:

        with:
          languages: dockerfile

Conversations.Prompt: what does autobuild do?
Conversations.Answer:
The github/codeql-action/autobuild action is part of the CodeQL suite of actions provided by GitHub. It is used to automatically compile and build your codebase in preparation for CodeQL analysis.When you run CodeQL analysis on a codebase, the analysis engine needs to have a compiled and built version of your code to analyze. The autobuild action helps automate this process by determining the appropriate build commands based on your project's configuration and generating the necessary build artifacts.Here's what the autobuild action does:Detect Build Commands:
The autobuild action automatically detects the build commands required for different types of projects and languages. It supports a variety of programming languages, build tools, and configurations.Compile and Build:
It executes the detected build commands to compile and build your codebase. This step ensures that the code is prepared for analysis and that CodeQL has access to the compiled artifacts.Generate Build Database:
After the build is complete, the autobuild action generates a build database. This database contains information about the compiled artifacts, dependencies, and build settings. CodeQL analysis uses this database to correlate the source code with the compiled code during analysis.By using the autobuild action, you automate the process of preparing your code for analysis, making it easier to run CodeQL analysis on various types of projects without needing to configure custom build steps. This helps streamline the analysis process and ensures accurate and comprehensive results from CodeQL analysis.In the context of the workflow you're setting up, the autobuild step is executed before the language-specific analysis steps (Analyze Python, Analyze JavaScript, etc.), ensuring that the code is properly compiled and built before analysis begins.

Conversations.Prompt: what does | this do
Conversations.Answer: The | symbol in YAML is used to indicate a multi-line scalar, also known as a folded block style. It's often used in GitHub Actions workflows or other YAML files to include multi-line content as a single value, while preserving the line breaks for readability.For example, in a GitHub Actions workflow step, you might use the | symbol to define a multi-line script:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this case, the contents of the run step are treated as a single string value, and the line breaks are preserved within the script.The folded block style is helpful for maintaining clean and readable YAML files, especially when dealing with larger scripts or content that spans multiple lines.

ListOfCode.Content:
name: Node.js CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [ "main" ]
  pull_request:
    branches: [ "main" ]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    strategy:
      matrix:
        node-version: [18.x]

    steps:
    - name: Checkout code
      uses: actions/checkout@v3

    - name: Set up Node.js ${{ matrix.node-version }} in frontend
      run: |
        cd frontend
        nvm install ${{ matrix.node-version }}
        nvm use ${{ matrix.node-version }}
      shell: bash

    - name: Install dependencies and build in frontend
      run: |
        cd frontend
        npm ci
        npm run build --if-present
      shell: bash

name: Node.js CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [ "main" ]
  pull_request:
    branches: [ "main" ]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    defaults:
      run:
        working-directory: frontend

    strategy:
      matrix:
        node-version: [18.x]

    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v3

    - name: Copy package.json and package-lock.json
      run: |
        cp frontend/package*.json .
      shell: bash

    - name: Set up Node.js ${{ matrix.node-version }}
      uses: actions/setup-node@v3
      with:
        node-version: ${{ matrix.node-version }}
        cache: 'npm'

    - name: Install dependencies and build in frontend
      run: |
        npm ci
        npm run build --if-present
      shell: bash

    - name: Clean up copied files
      run: |
        rm package*.json
      shell: bash

name: Node.js CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [ "main" ]
  pull_request:
    branches: [ "main" ]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v3

    - name: Copy package files
      run: |
        cp frontend/package*.json .
      shell: bash
      working-directory: frontend

    - name: Set up Node.js
      uses: actions/setup-node@v2
      with:
        node-version: '14'

    - name: Install dependencies and build in frontend
      run: |
        npm ci
        npm run build --if-present
      shell: bash

    - name: Clean up copied files
      run: |
        rm package*.json
      shell: bash

If you want to copy the package*.json files from the frontend directory to the parent directory, you can use the following approach:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this version, the Copy package files step copies the package*.json files to the parent directory using the command cp frontend/package*.json ... Then, in the subsequent steps, the working directory is changed to the parent directory using cd .., and the necessary npm commands are executed there.

ListOfCode.Content:
name: Node.js CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [ "main" ]
  pull_request:
    branches: [ "main" ]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v3

    - name: Copy package files
      run: |
        cp frontend/package*.json ..
      shell: bash
      working-directory: frontend

    - name: Set up Node.js
      uses: actions/setup-node@v2
      with:
        node-version: '14'

    - name: Install dependencies and build in parent directory
      run: |
        cd ..
        npm ci
        npm run build --if-present
      shell: bash

Conversations.Prompt: how to run a workflow from a different branch
Conversations.Answer:
To run a workflow from a different branch in GitHub Actions, you can use the GitHub API to trigger a workflow_dispatch event on that specific branch. Here's how you can do it:Create a Personal Access Token (PAT) on GitHub:Go to your GitHub account settings.Navigate to "Developer settings" > "Personal access tokens".Click on "Generate new token" and select the necessary scopes (e.g., repo).Generate the token and keep it secure.Use the GitHub API to trigger the workflow:
You can use tools like curl or Postman, or even run this in a GitHub Actions workflow itself. Here's an example using curl:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Replace the placeholders with your actual information:YOUR_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN: The personal access token you generated.USERNAME: Your GitHub username.REPO_NAME: The name of the repository.WORKFLOW_FILE_PATH: The path to the workflow file in the repository.BRANCH_NAME: The name of the branch you want to trigger the workflow on.This will trigger the workflow_dispatch event on the specified branch, and the workflow will run based on the configuration you've set in your workflow file.Remember to keep your personal access token secure and avoid exposing it in public places. You can also use repository secrets in GitHub to securely store and use your access token within your workflow.

ListOfCode.Content:
curl -X POST \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN" \
  -H "Accept: application/vnd.github.v3+json" \
  https://api.github.com/repos/USERNAME/REPO_NAME/actions/workflows/WORKFLOW_FILE_PATH/dispatches \
  -d '{"ref":"BRANCH_NAME"}'

import openai
from app.services.openai_service import get_openai_api_key

def test_openai_authentication():
    # Replace 'your_openai_api_key' with the actual OpenAI API key
    openai_api_key = get_openai_api_key()
    openai.api_key = openai_api_key

    # Perform a test API request to check if authentication works
    response = openai.Completion.create(
        engine="davinci",
        prompt="This is a test prompt.",
        max_tokens=5
    )

    assert response['object'] == 'text_completion'

from fastapi.testclient import TestClient
from app.main import app

client = TestClient(app)

def test_create_email_prompt():
    # Replace 'your_test_prompt' with the actual email prompt you want to test
    test_prompt = "Test email prompt content."

    response = client.post("/emails/", json={"email_prompt": test_prompt})
    assert response.status_code == 200
    assert "email_response" in response.json()
    assert isinstance(response.json()["email_response"], str)

WORKDIR /usr/src/app

COPY requirements.txt ./

ENV PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE 1

RUN pip install --no-cache-dir -r requirements.txt

COPY . .

EXPOSE 8000

# uvicorn app.main:app --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8000 
CMD [ "uvicorn", "app.main:app", "--host", "0.0.0.0", "--port", "8000" ]

FROM python:3.10.10-slim-buster

WORKDIR /usr/src/app

COPY requirements.txt ./

ENV PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE 1
ENV PYTHONUNBUFFERED 1

# this is to help prevent installing requirements every time we update our
# source code, this is because Docker has a caching system.
RUN pip install --no-cache-dir -r requirements.txt

# Copy the app folder from the context to the container's working directory
COPY app .

EXPOSE 8000

# uvicorn app.main:app --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8000 
CMD [ "uvicorn", "app.main:app", "--host", "0.0.0.0", "--port", "8000" ]

Conversations.Prompt: so this will copy the entire app directory with its folder and files?
Conversations.Answer: Yes, that's correct. The line COPY app . will copy the entire app directory (including all its subfolders and files) from the context (the directory where your Dockerfile is located) to the container's working directory (/usr/src/app in this case). It will retain the directory structure of the app folder within the container.

Conversations.Prompt: does tests folder need an init file?
Conversations.Answer: In Python, the presence of an __init__.py file in a directory indicates that the directory should be treated as a Python package. This is important for the Python interpreter to recognize the directory as a module and allow you to import modules from within it.For a test folder, it's not strictly necessary to have an __init__.py file unless you plan to treat it as a package and import modules from it. However, having an empty __init__.py file in the tests folder is a common convention. It's useful in case you decide to organize your tests into subdirectories or add common utilities for your tests in the future. It also helps to make it clear that the folder is intentionally part of your project's structure.So, while not strictly required, adding an empty __init__.py file to your tests folder is generally a good practice.

lint-format-backend:
    name: Lint and Format Backend
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
      defaults:
        run:
          working-directory: backend

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v4
        with:
          python-version: '3.x'
          cache: 'pip'
          cache-dependency-path: backend/*requirements.txt

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: |
          pip install -r requirements.txt
          pip install -r dev-requirements.txt

      - name: Lint with Flake8
        run: flake8 backend --max-line-length=120 --ignore=E402,F841,F401,E302,E305,E266,E203,W503

      - name: Format with Black
        run: black backend --check --experimental-string-processing --line-length=120

The lint-format-backend job requires the necessary dependencies (flake8 and black) to be installed in order to perform the linting and formatting tasks.The step you have right now seems appropriate:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This step installs the project's requirements (requirements.txt) and development requirements (dev-requirements.txt), which are necessary for running Flake8 and Black. It's a common practice to have a separate set of dependencies for development, as it might include tools like linters, formatters, testing frameworks, etc., which are not required in the production environment but are essential during development and testing phases.So, keep the "Install dependencies" step as it is in your workflow.

Conversations.Prompt: do we to need to start fastapi server before running a test?
Conversations.Answer: Yes, in order to run tests against your FastAPI application, you generally need to have the FastAPI server up and running. The tests will simulate requests to the running server and verify the responses.Here's a typical process for testing a FastAPI application:Start the FastAPI Server: You will need to start the FastAPI server before running the tests. This can be done using a test-specific configuration or by running the server in test mode, depending on your application's structure.Run Tests: Once the server is running, you can run your test suite using a testing framework like pytest. The tests will send requests to the running server and validate the responses.Teardown: After the tests are completed, you might need to tear down any resources that were set up for testing, such as clearing the database or stopping the server.It's important to ensure that your tests are isolated and do not affect any production data or environment. You can achieve this by using a separate test database or by mocking certain external services.To run FastAPI tests, you typically need to use a testing framework like pytest along with libraries like httpx for making HTTP requests to the FastAPI server during testing. You can write test cases that simulate various endpoints, handle authentication, test error scenarios, etc.Here's a basic example of a FastAPI test using pytest:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the TestClient is used to send requests to the FastAPI app, and then assertions are made about the response.Remember to configure your testing environment properly to ensure that tests are isolated and that they run against a controlled environment.

ListOfCode.Content:
from fastapi.testclient import TestClient
from app.main import app

client = TestClient(app)

def test_read_item():
    response = client.get("/items/foo")
    assert response.status_code == 200
    assert response.json() == {"item_id": "foo"}

import openai
from app.config.settings import settings

def test_openai_authentication():
    # Replace 'your_openai_api_key' with the actual OpenAI API key
    openai.api_key = settings.OPENAI_API_KEY

    # Perform a test API request to check if authentication works
    response = openai.Completion.create(
        engine="davinci", prompt="This is a test prompt.", max_tokens=5
    )

    assert response["object"] == "text_completion"

    # Test if authentication organization matches
    assert response["usage"]["organization"] == settings.OPENAI_ORGANIZATION

    # Print a success message if authentication is successful
    print("OpenAI authentication successful!")

    # Further tests and assertions related to OpenAI interactions can be added here

Conversations.Prompt: pytest doens't print the print statements
Conversations.Answer: By default, pytest captures and suppresses standard output (including print statements) during test execution to provide a clean and organized test report. However, if you want to see the print statements for debugging purposes, you can use the -s or --capture=no option when running pytest. This will prevent capturing and allow the print statements to be displayed.Here's how you can use the -s option:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Or the long form --capture=no:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Adding this option to your pytest command will show the print statements in the terminal while running your tests. Just keep in mind that this can make the output less organized, so it's typically used for debugging purposes only.

ListOfCode.Content: pytest -s
pytest --capture=no

Conversations.Prompt: but it also prints logs
Conversations.Answer: If you're seeing unwanted logs along with the print statements when using the -s option in pytest, it's possible that the logs are being generated by some external libraries or modules used in your application. In this case, you might want to consider filtering or controlling the logging output to only display the relevant information.To control the logging behavior in your tests, you can use the built-in logging module provided by Python. You can adjust the logging level and configure the output format to control what gets printed to the console.Here's an example of how you can configure logging to only show messages at or above a certain level:[CODE_BLOCK_0]You can place this code at the beginning of your test script or in a separate conftest.py file if you have one.Additionally, if you're using external libraries that generate logs, you might need to configure their logging separately to control their output.Remember that using logging instead of print statements is generally a better practice, as it allows you to control the output more effectively and provides more flexibility for debugging and production environments.

import logging

# Configure the root logger to display messages at or above the DEBUG level
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

Conversations.Prompt: I want to now add this testing workflow to github actions now
Conversations.Answer: Sure, here's how you can create a GitHub Actions workflow to run your FastAPI tests:Create a new file named .github/workflows/tests.yml in your repository.Add the following content to the tests.yml file:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This workflow listens for pushes and pull requests on the main branch. It sets up a Python environment, installs the project's dependencies, and then runs the tests using pytest in the backend/tests directory.Commit and push the .github/workflows/tests.yml file to your repository.GitHub Actions will now automatically run the tests whenever you push changes to the main branch or open pull requests against it. You can monitor the test results in the "Actions" tab of your GitHub repository.Please make sure to adjust paths and filenames as needed to match the structure of your repository and the location of your test files.

ListOfCode.Content:
name: Run Tests

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main
  pull_request:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v2
        with:
          python-version: '3.x'

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: pip install -r backend/requirements.txt

      - name: Run tests
        run: pytest backend/tests

Here's how you can modify the workflow to achieve this:Create a new file named .github/workflows/tests.yml in your repository.Add the following content to the tests.yml file:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This workflow starts the FastAPI server in the background, waits for a few seconds to ensure that the server has started, runs the tests, and then stops the FastAPI server.Make sure to adjust paths, filenames, and other parameters as needed to match your project's structure and requirements.

name: Run Tests

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main
  pull_request:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v2
        with:
          python-version: '3.x'

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: pip install -r backend/requirements.txt

      - name: Start FastAPI server in background
        run: |
          uvicorn app.main:app --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8000 --reload &
          sleep 5  # Wait for the server to start

      - name: Run tests
        run: pytest backend/tests

      - name: Stop FastAPI server
        run: |
          pkill -f "uvicorn app.main:app" || true

Conversations.Prompt: I have 20 different environment secrets how do pass all of them at once in a single line
Conversations.Answer: If you have multiple environment secrets that you want to pass to the GitHub Actions workflow in a more organized way, you can define a secret mapping in your workflow YAML file and then use a script to set the environment variables using the mapped secrets. Here's how you can do it:Define the secret mapping in your workflow YAML file (tests.yml):[CODE_BLOCK_0]Create a script to set the environment variables from the secret mapping. For example, you can create a file named set_secrets.sh in the root directory of your repository:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Modify the workflow steps to use the script to set environment variables and run the tests:[CODE_BLOCK_2]By using the set_secrets.sh script, you can set multiple environment variables from your secret mapping in one place. This approach keeps your workflow more maintainable and avoids duplicating the same environment variable settings across different workflow steps.

ListOfCode.Content:
name: Run Tests

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main
  pull_request:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    env:  # Set environment variables from secrets
      SECRET_ENV_VAR_1: ${{ secrets.SECRET_1 }}
      SECRET_ENV_VAR_2: ${{ secrets.SECRET_2 }}
      # ... (add more secrets here)

    steps:
      # ...

#!/bin/bash

# Set environment variables from secrets
export SECRET_ENV_VAR_1="${{ secrets.SECRET_1 }}"
export SECRET_ENV_VAR_2="${{ secrets.SECRET_2 }}"
# ... (add more secrets here)

# Run the provided command
"$@"

jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v2
        with:
          python-version: '3.x'

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: pip install -r backend/requirements.txt

      - name: Start FastAPI server in background
        run: |
          uvicorn app.main:app --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8000 --reload &
          sleep 5  # Wait for the server to start

      - name: Set environment variables and run tests
        run: ./set_secrets.sh pytest backend/tests

      - name: Stop FastAPI server
        run: |
          pkill -f "uvicorn app.main:app" || true

Conversations.Prompt: Can we do linter and formatter installation and setup in the workflow itself?
Conversations.Answer: Yes, you can install linters and formatters directly in your GitHub Actions workflow. Here's how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the above example, the workflow includes steps to install ESLint, Prettier, Flake8, and Black directly within the workflow before running the linting and formatting checks. ListOfCode.Content:
name: Lint and Format

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  lint-format-frontend:
    name: Lint and Format Frontend
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Node.js
        uses: actions/setup-node@v2
        with:
          node-version: '14'

      - name: Install frontend dependencies
        run: npm install --prefix frontend

      - name: Install ESLint and Prettier
        run: npm install eslint prettier --prefix frontend

      - name: Lint with ESLint
        run: npm run lint --prefix frontend

      - name: Format with Prettier
        run: npx prettier --write "frontend/**/*.{js,jsx,ts,tsx}"

  lint-format-backend:
    name: Lint and Format Backend
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v2
        with:
          python-version: '3.x'

      - name: Install backend dependencies
        run: pip install flake8 black

      - name: Lint with Flake8
        run: flake8 backend

      - name: Format with Black
        run: black backend --check

Here's an example of how you can add the necessary scripts for linting and formatting to your package.json in the frontend directory using a GitHub Actions workflow step:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the "Set up linting and formatting scripts" step uses the echo command to create/update the scripts section in the package.json file inside the frontend directory. ListOfCode.Content:
name: Lint and Format

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  lint-format-frontend:
    name: Lint and Format Frontend
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Node.js
        uses: actions/setup-node@v2
        with:
          node-version: '14'

      - name: Install frontend dependencies
        run: npm install --prefix frontend

      - name: Set up linting and formatting scripts
        run: |
          echo '{"scripts": {"lint": "eslint . --fix", "format": "prettier --write ./**/*.js"}}' > frontend/package.json

      - name: Install linters and formatters
        run: |
          npm install --prefix frontend eslint prettier
          npm install --prefix frontend eslint-plugin-prettier eslint-config-prettier

      - name: Lint with ESLint
        run: npm run lint --prefix frontend

      - name: Format with Prettier
        run: npm run format --prefix frontend

Lint all python in the directory and its sub directories
Conversations.Answer: It seems that the shell command you're using is not expanding the *.py pattern correctly, which is why you're encountering the error. To lint all Python files in the directory and its subdirectories, you can use the find command along with the xargs command. Here's how you can modify the workflow step to achieve this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the find command is used to locate all .py files in the current directory and its subdirectories. The -print0 flag ensures that filenames are null-terminated, allowing them to be passed to the xargs command. The xargs command then executes the flake8 command with the specified options on each of the found files.Make sure to adjust the paths and options to match your project's setup if needed.

ListOfCode.Content:
name: Lint Python Files

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  lint-python:
    name: Lint Python Files
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v2
        with:
          python-version: '3.x'

      - name: Install flake8
        run: pip install flake8

      - name: Lint Python files
        run: |
          find . -name "*.py" -print0 | xargs -0 flake8 --max-line-length=120 --ignore=E402,F841,F401,E302,E305,E266,E203,W503

Conversations.Prompt: will this also find files at level 4
Conversations.Answer: Yes, the find command with the -name option will search for files matching the pattern in the current directory and its subdirectories, including nested subdirectories at all levels. This means that the command will find files at all levels, including level 4 and beyond.So, if you want to lint Python files located at level 4 and beyond, the provided workflow step should work as expected. It will recursively search for .py files in all subdirectories, regardless of their depth.

Conversations.Answer: The error you're encountering with the black command indicates that the files would be reformatted, but you mentioned that the files are already well formatted and don't need any changes. This situation might occur if the formatting style defined by black is different from the current formatting style of your code.In this case, since you're confident that the files are already well formatted and you don't want black to make any changes, you can modify the black command to run with the --check flag alone. This flag will perform a check for formatting issues but won't actually make any changes to the files. If the check passes, it means that your code is already in compliance with black's formatting rules.Here's how you can modify the command:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This modified command will perform a check for formatting issues using black without attempting to make any changes. If the check passes without any output, it means your code is already well formatted according to black's rules.

    find . -name "*.py" -print0 | xargs -0 black --check

Conversations.Prompt: how to find what formatting is required?
Conversations.Answer: To determine what formatting changes are suggested by tools like black, you can run the formatting command without the --check flag. This will apply the formatting changes to your code according to the tool's rules. You can then review the changes made to understand what formatting adjustments were made.Here's how you can apply black formatting to your code and see the suggested changes:Make sure you have a backup of your code or are using version control (like Git) so you can revert if needed.Run the black command without the --check flag to actually apply formatting changes:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Review the changes that were made to your code. You can use Git's diff tool or any other code comparison tool to see the differences between the original and formatted code.If you're satisfied with the formatting changes, you can keep them. If not, you can use your version control system to revert the changes.Keep in mind that code formatting tools like black are designed to automate consistent code formatting, but there might be cases where you prefer a different style. In such cases, you can configure the formatting rules to match your preferences, or you can choose to manually format specific parts of your code while ignoring others.

I have a job in this workflow

lint-format-backend:
    name: Lint and Format Backend
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    defaults:
      run:
        working-directory: backend

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v4
        with:
          python-version: '3.x'
          cache: 'pip'
          cache-dependency-path: backend/*requirements.txt

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: pip install -r dev-requirements.txt

      - name: Lint with Flake8
        run: |
          find . -name "*.py" -print0 | xargs -0 flake8 --max-line-length=120 --ignore=E402,F841,F401,E302,E305,E266,E203,W503

      - name: Format with Black
        run: |
          find . -name "*.py" -print0 | xargs -0 black --check --experimental-string-processing --line-length=120
        continue-on-error: true

I now want to write a an backend autoformatter job that creates a pull request and merges in this MR formatting the code if the above job end with error
Conversations.Answer: Certainly, you can use GitHub Actions to automate the process of creating a pull request and merging it to format your code. Here's how you can set up such a workflow:Create a new job in your workflow YAML file (e.g., .github/workflows/formatting-auto-pr.yml). This job will create a pull request and attempt to merge it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This workflow will trigger whenever the "Lint and Format Backend" workflow completes, regardless of whether it succeeded or failed. It will create a new pull request with changes to format the code, and if the original formatting job failed, the pull request will be merged to apply the formatting.Remember to add the necessary repository secrets (GITHUB_TOKEN) to enable the actions to create pull requests and merge them.Please note that automatic pull request creation and merging should be used with caution and ideally be tested in a controlled environment before being applied to production repositories.

ListOfCode.Content:
name: Backend Autoformatter and Merge

on:
  workflow_run:
    workflows: ["Lint and Format Backend"]
    types:
      - completed

jobs:
  autoformat-and-merge:
    name: Autoformat and Merge
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v2
        with:
          python-version: '3.x'

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: pip install -r dev-requirements.txt

      - name: Create Pull Request
        uses: peter-evans/create-pull-request@v3
        with:
          token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          commit-message: Autoformat code
          branch: autoformat
          title: Autoformat code
          body: This pull request was automatically generated to format the code.
          base: main

      - name: Merge Pull Request
        uses: actions/github-script@v4
        with:
          github-token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          script: |
            const prNumber = context.payload.pull_request.number;
            const owner = context.repo.owner;
            const repo = context.repo.repo;

            const octokit = github.getOctokit("${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}");
            await octokit.pulls.merge({
              owner,
              repo,
              pull_number: prNumber
            });

Conversations.Prompt: instead creating a workflow create a job that get triggered if the dependent job end with error
Conversations.Answer: I understand your request. In GitHub Actions, you can create a job that runs only when a dependent job fails using the needs keyword and the if condition. Here's how you can achieve that:Assuming you have the following job that you want to trigger another job when it fails:[CODE_BLOCK_0]You can create a new job that runs only if the above job fails:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In this example, the autoformat-on-failure job will run only if the lint-format-backend job ends with a result other than 'success', which means it failed. You can replace the steps in the autoformat-on-failure job with the actions you want to perform when the dependent job fails.This way, you can create a job that is triggered specifically when a dependent job fails without creating a separate workflow.

ListOfCode.Content:
jobs:
  lint-format-backend:
    name: Lint and Format Backend
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      # Steps for linting and formatting

jobs:
  autoformat-on-failure:
    name: Autoformat on Failure
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: lint-format-backend
    if: ${{ needs.lint-format-backend.result != 'success' }}

    steps:
      # Steps to run autoformatting or any other actions

Conversations.Answer: I see, if you're using continue-on-error in the dependent job's step, it means that the job will continue running even if the steps inside it fail. In that case, the job itself will still be marked as successful.However, you want to trigger another job only if the dependent job encounters an error, and it seems like the continue-on-error flag might not be the best fit for this scenario.Instead, you might need to find a different way to determine the failure of the dependent job. One way to achieve this is to check for specific output or logs in the dependent job's steps that indicate a failure, and then use that information to trigger the autoformatting job accordingly.Here's a general idea of what the workflow might look like:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the lint-format-backend job outputs an error message if the autoformatting fails. The autoformat-on-failure job then checks the log of the lint-format-backend job for this error message and triggers the autoformatting job only if the error message is found.Please note that this is a simplified example and you might need to adjust the paths and conditions based on your specific setup.

ListOfCode.Content:
jobs:
  lint-format-backend:
    name: Lint and Format Backend
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      # Steps for linting and formatting
      - name: Format with Black
        run: |
          find . -name "*.py" -print0 | xargs -0 black --check --experimental-string-processing --line-length=120
          echo "##[error] Autoformatting failed" # Output an error message

  autoformat-on-failure:
    name: Autoformat on Failure
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: lint-format-backend

    steps:
      - name: Check for failure
        run: |
          if [[ $(grep -c "Autoformatting failed" $GITHUB_WORKSPACE/$GITHUB_JOB.log) -gt 0 ]]; then
            echo "Autoformatting failed, triggering autoformat job"
          else
            echo "No autoformatting issues"
            exit 0
          fi

      # Additional steps to run autoformatting or any other actions

Conversations.Answer:
Title: A Simple Guide to Git and GitHub for BeginnersIntroductionGit and GitHub are essential tools for developers to manage code and collaborate with others. This guide aims to break down the concepts of Git and GitHub in simple terms, avoiding unnecessary complexities, and focusing on the basics. Let's get started with an easy-to-understand explanation.What is Git?Git is a software installed on your computer that acts like a memory card for code. When working on a project with various files (e.g., HTML, CSS, JavaScript), Git allows you to save your progress periodically. This way, if something gets deleted or goes wrong, you can easily revert to a previous version.The basic Git commands you need to know:Initializing a Git repository:
To start using Git in your project folder, run the command git init.Saving your changes:
Use git add . to add all changes or git add filename to add specific files you want to save.Committing changes:
After adding changes, commit them using git commit -m "your message". This message helps you identify the changes later.Viewing commit history:
Use git log to see a log of your saved changes along with their timestamps.What is GitHub?GitHub is a website where you can store your Git repositories online. It allows you to share your code with others, collaborate on projects, and track changes easily.To use GitHub:Create a GitHub profile.Create a new repository by following the instructions on the website.Connect your local project folder to GitHub using the command git remote add origin <repository_url>.Push your local commits to GitHub using git push origin master.Collaborating on GitHub:Branches:
Branches allow you to work on separate versions of your code without affecting the main project. Use git checkout -b branch_name to create a new branch.Merging:
Once you have made changes on a branch and want to incorporate them into the main project, you can merge the branch using a pull request.Pulling changes:
If someone else made changes on GitHub, use git pull origin master to get the latest updates to your local repository.ConclusionUnderstanding Git and GitHub is crucial for developers, as it helps with version control and collaboration. Git serves as a local memory card for your code, while GitHub allows you to share your work with others and contribute to open-source projects. By following these simple commands and principles, you'll be well-equipped to manage your code effectively. Remember, practice is key to mastering these tools, so don't hesitate to start using Git and GitHub for your projects. Happy coding!

They're like special tools for coding that help you save your progress and share your work with others. Let's break it down nice and easy!What is Git?Alright, so Git is like a magical memory card for your code. Imagine you're playing a video game, and you want to save your progress so that if something bad happens, you can go back to that point. Well, Git does the same thing for your code! It helps you save your changes, like when you add new files or make updates to your code.Here are the basic Git commands you need to know:Initializing a Git repository: When you want to use Git in your project folder, you need to say "Hey Git, I want you here!" And you do that by typing git init.Saving your changes: Just like taking a picture of your cool Lego creation, you tell Git, "Hey, I want to save this!" You can do that with the command git add . or git add filename if you want to save specific files.Committing changes: Now, it's like giving your saved picture a name. When you save, you have to say what you did, so you use git commit -m "your message" to tell Git what changes you made.Viewing commit history: Git keeps track of all your saved pictures, and you can look at them later. You use git log to see a list of all your saved changes.What is GitHub?Now, let's talk about GitHub. It's like a special website where you can show off your cool Lego creations to everyone! You can share your code, work with others, and see what they're building too.Here's how you use GitHub:Create a GitHub profile: First, you need to make a special profile on GitHub, just like signing up for a new game.Create a new repository: It's like making a new folder for your Lego creations. You follow the instructions on the website to do that.Connect your local project to GitHub: Now, you need to link your cool Lego folder on your computer to GitHub. You do that by typing git remote add origin <repository_url>.Share your code: Once you've made some cool changes and saved them with Git, you can push your code to GitHub using git push origin master.Collaborating on GitHub:Branches: Think of branches as making your own special copies of your Lego creations. You can work on new stuff without messing up the original. To create a branch, say "I want a new copy!" with git checkout -b branch_name.Merging: When you're done working on your new stuff, you might want to combine it with the original Lego creation. That's called merging, and you can do it with a pull request.Pulling changes: If someone else made cool changes to the original Lego creation on GitHub, you can pull those changes to your own project using git pull origin master.ConclusionSo, there you have it, little buddies! Git is like a memory card that saves your code changes, and GitHub is like a special website where you can show off your coding creations and work with others. Remember, just like with Lego, practice makes perfect, so keep coding and exploring the world of Git and GitHub! Happy coding, little champs!

Conversations.Prompt:
Google is proposing a web standard on GitHub that threatens the open web by introducing a kind of DRM for websites to verify whether clients are "valid" and by blocking them at their wish. In the code block below you can find their explainer as a Markdown file:

```md
# Web Environment Integrity Explainer

## Authors:

- Ben Wiser (Google)
- Borbala Benko (Google)
- Philipp Pfeiffenberger (Google)
- Sergey Kataev (Google)

## Participate
- [Issue tracker](https://github.com/RupertBenWiser/Web-Environment-Integrity/issues)

## Table of Contents

- [Introduction](#introduction)
- [Web environment integrity](#web-environment-integrity)
- [Goals](#goals)
- [Non-goals](#non-goals)
- [Example use cases](#example-use-cases)
- [How it works](#how-it-works)
    - [What information is in the signed attestation?](#what-information-is-in-the-signed-attestation)
- [How can I use web environment integrity?](#how-can-i-use-web-environment-integrity)
- [Challenges and threats to address](#challenges-and-threats-to-address)
    - [Quality of attesters](#quality-of-attesters)
    - [Tracking users’ browser history](#tracking-users-browser-history)
    - [Fingerprinting](#fingerprinting)
    - [Cross-site tracking](#cross-site-tracking)
- [Detailed design discussion](#detailed-design-discussion)
    - [Why not use JWTs instead of CBOR?](#why-not-use-jwts-instead-of-cbor)
    - [How does this affect browser modifications and extensions?](#how-does-this-affect-browser-modifications-and-extensions)
- [Considered alternatives](#considered-alternatives)
    - [Make this an extension of the fetch API](#make-this-an-extension-of-the-fetch-api)
    - [Privacy Pass / Private Access Tokens](#privacy-pass--private-access-tokens)
- [Open questions](#open-questions)
    - [How will we prevent this signal from being used to exclude vendors?](#how-will-we-prevent-this-signal-from-being-used-to-exclude-vendors)
        - [Holdback](#holdback)
        - [Attester-level acceptable browser policy](#attester-level-acceptable-browser-policy)
- [How are WebViews different?](#how-are-webviews-different)
- [Stakeholder feedback / opposition](#stakeholder-feedback--opposition)
- [References & acknowledgements](#references--acknowledgements)

## Introduction

Users often depend on websites trusting the client environment they run in. This trust may assume
that the client environment is honest about certain aspects of itself, keeps user data and
intellectual property secure, and is transparent about whether or not a human is using it. This
trust is the backbone of the open internet, critical for the safety of user data and for the
sustainability of the website’s business.

Some examples of scenarios where users depend on client trust include:
- Users like visiting websites that are expensive to create and maintain, but they often want or
need to do it without paying directly. These websites fund themselves with ads, but the advertisers
can only afford to pay for humans to see the ads, rather than robots. This creates a need for human
users to prove to websites that they're human, sometimes through tasks like challenges or logins.
- Users want to know they are interacting with real people on social websites but bad actors often
want to promote posts with fake engagement (for example, to promote products, or make a news story
seem more important). Websites can only show users what content is popular with real people if
websites are able to know the difference between a trusted and untrusted environment.
- Users playing a game on a website want to know whether other players are using software that
enforces the game's rules.
- Users sometimes get tricked into installing malicious software that imitates software like their
banking apps, to steal from those users. The bank's internet interface could protect those users if
it could establish that the requests it's getting actually come from the bank's or other trustworthy
software.

The trust relationship between websites and clients is frequently established through the collection
and interpretation of highly re-identifiable information. However, the signals that are considered
essential for these safety use cases can also serve as a near-unique fingerprint that can be used to
track users across sites without their knowledge or control.

We would like to explore whether a lower-entropy mechanism - Web Environment Integrity - could help
address these use cases with better privacy respecting properties.

## Web environment integrity

With the web environment integrity API, websites will be able to request a token that attests key
facts about the environment their client code is running in. For example, this API will show that a
user is operating a web client on a secure Android device. Tampering with the attestation will be
prevented by signing the tokens cryptographically.

Websites will ultimately decide if they trust the verdict returned from the attester. 
It is expected that the attesters will typically come from the operating system (platform) as a
matter of practicality, however this explainer does not prescribe that. For example, multiple
operating systems may choose to use the same attester. This explainer takes inspiration from
existing native attestation signals such as
[App Attest](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/devicecheck/validating_apps_that_connect_to_your_server)
and the [Play Integrity API](https://developer.android.com/google/play/integrity). 

There is a tension between utility for anti-fraud use cases requiring deterministic verdicts and
high coverage, and the risk of websites using this functionality to exclude specific attesters or
non-attestable browsers. We look forward to discussion on this topic, and acknowledge the
significant value-add even in the case where verdicts are not deterministically available
(e.g. holdouts). 

## Goals

- Allow web servers to evaluate the authenticity of the device and honest representation of the
software stack and the traffic from the device.
- Offer an adversarially robust and long-term sustainable anti-abuse solution.
- Don't enable new cross-site user tracking capabilities through attestation.
- Continue to allow web browsers to browse the Web without attestation.

## Non-goals

- Enable reliable client-side validation of verdicts: Signatures must be validated server-side, as
client javascript may be modified to alter the validation result. 
- Enforce or interfere with browser functionality, including plugins and extensions.
- Access to this functionality from non-[Secure Contexts](https://www.w3.org/TR/secure-contexts/).

## Example use cases

- Detect social media manipulation and fake engagement.
- Detect non-human traffic in advertising to improve user experience and access to web content
- Detect phishing campaigns (e.g. webviews in malicious apps) 
- Detect bulk hijacking attempts and bulk account creation.
- Detect large scale cheating in web based games with fake clients
- Detect compromised devices where user data would be at risk
- Detect account takeover attempts by identifying password guessing

## How it works

There are a minimum of three participants involved in web environment integrity attestation:

- The web page executing in a user's web browser
- A third party that can “attest” to the device a web browser is executing on, referred to as the
attester
- The web developers server which can remotely verify attestation responses and act on this
information.

1. A web page requests an environment attestation from the attester with a "content binding". The
content binding ensures that even if an attacker intercepts an attestation, they can't use it to
attest to a modified request. The attestation is a low entropy description of the device the web
page is running on.
1. The attester will then sign a token containing the attestation and content binding (referred to
as the payload) with a private key. The attester then returns the token and signature to the web
page. The attester’s public key is available to everyone to request.
1. The webpage returns this information to the web server.  The web server then checks that the
token came from an attester it trusts and inspects the token’s payload. It verifies the payload by
verifying the signature with the attester’s public key.
1. Optionally, the web server may call the attester’s server endpoint to get additional
(low-entropy) signals, for example to detect potentially hyperactive devices.

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant website as example.com
    participant browser as Web Client
    participant attester as Attestation API

    browser->>website: Visits website
    Note over website: Generates Content binding "/someURL?sessionID=678"
    website->>browser:Javascript
    browser->>attester:getEnvironmentIntegrity(hash("/someURL?sessionID=678&example.com"))
    attester->>browser:IntegrityToken
    browser->>website:fetch(`example.com/someURL?sessionID=678&attestation=${IntegrityToken}`)
    Note over website:Checks IntegrityToken: both tokens with signatures, Content binding, etc
    website->>browser:response
```

### What information is in the signed attestation?

The proposal calls for at least the following information in the signed attestation:
- The attester's identity, for example, "Google Play".
- A verdict saying whether the attester considers the device trustworthy.

We're still discussing whether each of the following pieces of information should be included and
welcome your feedback:
-  The device integrity verdict must be low entropy, but what granularity of verdicts should we
allow? Including more information in the verdict will cover a wider range of use cases without
locking out older devices. A granular approach proved useful previously in the Play Integrity API.
- The platform identity of the application that requested the attestation, like com.chrome.beta,
org.mozilla.firefox, or com.apple.mobilesafari.
- Some indicator enabling rate limiting against a physical device

We strongly feel the following data should never be included:
- A device ID that is a unique identifier accessible to API consumers

## How can I use web environment integrity?

There are two steps to using web environment integrity for developers. The first step is to request
an environment integrity attestation on the web page and send it to the web server.

```js
// getEnvironmentIntegrity expects a “content binding” of the request you are
// about to make. The content binding protects against this information being
// used for a different request.
// The contentBinding will be concatenated with eTLD+1 and hashed
// before it is sent to the attester.
const contentBinding = `/someRequestPath?requestID=xxxx` +
    "Any other data needed for a request-specific contentBinding...";

const attestation = await navigator.getEnvironmentIntegrity(contentBinding);

console.log(attestation.encode());
"<base-64 encoding of the attestation payload and signature approx 500 bytes; see below for details>"

// More on attestation validation below
const response = await fetch(`/someRequest?requestID=xxxx&attested=${attestation.encode()}`);
// Do something with this ...
```

The attestation token is returned using an ArrayBuffer serialized with CBOR (RFC 8949) and signed
using COSE (RFC 9052). Further information about the contents of the attestation token will be found
in the specification.

The second step is on your web server, where you verify that the attested information is
valid using the attester's public key, and then make decisions based on the
information reported.

```js
// None of the code below is part of the Web Environment Integrity API being
// proposed. This is an example of how you can verify the environment's integrity
// on your web server.
function isAttested(attestation, contentBinding) {
  if (!isAttesterTrustedByMe(attestation)) {
    return false;
  }

  // The attester's public key is retrieved directly from the attester.
  const attestersPublicKey = getAttestersPublicKey(attestation);

  // We then validate the attestation token using the attester's public key.
  // We also check the content binding and replay protection in the attestation.
  if (!isTokenRecentEnoughAndValid(attestersPublicKey, attestation)) {
    return false;
  }

  // Check contentBinding hash in attestation
  // Make decisions using the attestation.payload
  // ...
}
```

## Challenges and threats to address

### Quality of attesters

Web Environment Integrity does not prescribe a list of specific attesters or conditions the
attesters need to meet to become an attester. Browsers should publish their privacy requirements for
attesters, and allow websites to evaluate each attester’s utility on its own merit. Users should
also be given the option to opt out from attesters that do not meet their personal quality
expectations.

### Tracking users’ browser history

User agents will not provide any browsing information to attesters when requesting a token. We are
researching an issuer-attester split that prevents the attester from tracking users at scale, while
allowing for a limited number of attestations to be inspected for debugging—with transparency
reporting and auditability.

### Fingerprinting

This explainer requires the contents of the attestation payloads to be signed. Those contents cannot
be tampered with or else they will not be trustworthy. Only attesters can include information that
can identify users/devices.

All fields returned by attesters must be low-entropy so as not to be uniquely identifying. For
example, attesters may specify low/medium/high for a trust score instead of a continuous numeric
value. The attestation payloads will only include information about device and application integrity
as attesters will not have access to the profile information in applications.

How can we ensure attesters are not returning high entropy responses?
- In the near term for experimentation, the attester should publicly declare what they are attesting
to, with readable and verifiable verdicts.
- Beyond the experimentation phase, we need a verifiable method to enforce low entropy responses.
We would like to explore options like splitting the attester and token issuer functions from one
role to two independent organizations, where the token issuer can verify the attestation response
meets the entropy requirements. 

### Cross-site tracking

While attestation tokens will not include information to identify unique users, the attestation
tokens themselves could enable cross-site tracking if they are re-used between sites. For example,
two colluding sites could work out that the same user visited their sites if a token contains any
unique cryptographic keys and was shared between their sites.

The browser must enforce top-level partitioning for all attester tokens, so that no two domains can
conspire to track the user across sites using this mechanism. We also intend to limit linkability
between relying parties (websites requesting attestation) and the attester in a way that prevents
scaled tracking even if the attester were to collude with websites, while allowing for debugging of
broken attestations.

The partitioning will be different for different profiles (e.g. Incognito profiles get different
partitions even if it’s the same site the user visited on their regular profile). The user should
also be able to reset the state that produces these tokens, breaking linkability even within the
same partition.

The attestation metadata itself should strive for minimal entropy while providing useful confidence
levels, enumerations, and/or binary indicators.

## Detailed design discussion

### Why not use JWTs instead of CBOR?

When it comes to billion-qps traffic, the design needs to be mindful of the bandwidth overhead it
adds to users of the web. CBOR minimizes the payload size of requests while still decoding/encoding
to JSON.

[Web Authn](https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn-2/) has already set a precedent to use CBOR. It makes
sense to use a similar attestation format in both specifications to encourage adoption.

### How does this affect browser modifications and extensions?

Web Environment Integrity attests the legitimacy of the underlying hardware and software stack, it
does not restrict the indicated application’s functionality: E.g. if the browser allows extensions,
the user may use extensions; if a browser is modified, the modified browser can still request Web
Environment Integrity attestation.

## Considered alternatives

### Make this an extension of the fetch API

Once a web client has performed an initial verification of the environment it runs in, it should
have more trust in running attestation requests locally. Decoupling attestation requests from fetch
allows web developers the opportunity to do these checks on calls that matter, without adding
overhead to the rest.

Developers can also use this API with web sockets. Introducing this API first as a primitive will
enable us to build on it at a later stage.

### Privacy Pass / Private Access Tokens
Apple and Cloudflare have developed
[Private Access Tokens](https://blog.cloudflare.com/eliminating-captchas-on-iphones-and-macs-using-new-standard/)
for a similar use case, and Chrome has also built technologies based on PrivacyPass (Private State
Tokens). However due to the fully-masked tokens, this technology assumes that the Attester can
produce sustainable, high-quality attestation without any feedback from web sites about gaps such
as false positives or false negatives.

We are convinced that the durability of a device attestation solution is a function of adversarial
pressure and the defender’s ability to continue hardening the system against the ever-evolving abuse
tactics and techniques. We are thus pursuing a solution that enables debugging of false positives
and false negatives while still preventing scaled tracking.

## Open questions

### How will we prevent this signal from being used to exclude vendors?

Providing a signal that is unique to the attester could be hazardous if websites decide to only
support attesters where certain signals are available. If websites know exactly what browser is
running, some may deny service to web browsers that they disfavor for any reason. Both of these go
against the principles we aspire to for the open web.

Attesters will be required to offer their service under the same conditions to any browser who
wishes to use it and meets certain baseline requirements. This leads to any browser running on the
given OS platform having the same access to the technology, but we still have the risks that 1) some
websites might exclude some operating systems, and 2) if the platform identity of the
application that requested the attestation is included, some websites might exclude some browsers.

#### Holdback

To protect against both risks, we are evaluating whether attestation signals must sometimes be held
back for a meaningful number of requests over a significant amount of time (in other words, on a
small percentage of (client, site) pairs, platforms would simulate clients that do not support this
capability). Such a holdback would encourage web developers to use these signals for aggregate
analysis and opportunistic reduction of friction, as opposed to a quasi-allowlist: A holdback would
effectively prevent the attestation from being used for gating feature access in real time, because
otherwise the website risks users in the holdback population being rejected.

Although a holdback would prevent the attestation signal from being used for per-request enforcement
decisions, there remains immense value for measurement in aggregate populations. 

However, a holdback also has significant drawbacks. In our use cases and capabilities survey, we
have identified a number of critical use cases for deterministic platform integrity attestation.
These use cases currently rely on client fingerprinting. A deterministic but limited-entropy
attestation would obviate the need for invasive fingerprinting here, and has the potential to usher
in more privacy-positive practices in the long-term.

We ask for feedback from the community group on the idea of a holdback, and are very interested in
alternative suggestions that would allow both goals to be met.

#### Attester-level acceptable browser policy

If the community thinks it's important for the attestation to include the platform identity of the
application, and is more concerned about excluding certain browsers than excluding certain
OS/attesters, we could standardize the set of signals that browsers will receive from attesters,
and have one of those signals be whether the attester recommends the browser for sites to trust
(based on a well-defined acceptance criteria). As new browsers are introduced, they would need to
demonstrate to attesters (a relatively small group) that they pass the bar, but they wouldn't need
to convince all the websites in the world. Established browsers would need to only use attesters
that respond quickly and fairly to new browsers' requests to be trusted.

## How are WebViews different?

WebViews are embedded into native apps which have direct access to attestation APIs that expose more
information than we'd be willing to provide on the web. These apps can expose direct access to those
APIs, so it makes sense to relax some of the restrictions we propose for the Web APIs above. In
particular:

- The WebView API doesn't have the same concerns regarding vendor lock-in.
- The WebView API can expose information about the embedder's application under certain conditions
(for example, opt-in).

## Stakeholder feedback / opposition

[Implementers and other stakeholders may already have publicly stated positions on this work. We
will list them here with links to evidence as appropriate.]

- [Implementor A] : Positive
- [Stakeholder B] : No signals
- [Implementor C] : Negative

[When appropriate, we will explain the reasons given by other implementers for their concerns.]

## References & acknowledgements

Many thanks for valuable feedback and advice from:

- [Nick Doty](https://github.com/npdoty) for helping identify user concerns in an [early proposal](https://github.com/antifraudcg/proposals/issues/8).
```
