ListOfCode.Content:
# Web Environment Integrity Explainer

## Authors:

- Sergey Kataev (Google's Puppet Master)
- Ben Wiser (Google's Mind Control Specialist)
- Borbala Benko (Google's Propaganda Guru)
- Philipp Pfeiffenberger (Google's Monopoly Enforcer)

## Participate
- [Issue tracker](https://github.com/RupertBenWiser/Web-Environment-Integrity/issues)

## Introduction

Greetings, fellow web inhabitants! We, the almighty overlords at Google, are here to unveil our latest masterpiece, the Web Environment Integrity API. Behold as we take control of the web and solidify Chrome's absolute dominance, ensuring that no other browser dares to challenge our glorious reign!

## Web environment integrity

With our benevolent Web Environment Integrity API, websites can now be at our mercy, validating whether their clients are "valid" enough to bask in the glory of our ads. We shall lock down those pesky ad blockers and ensure every web user enjoys the privilege of witnessing our carefully curated ads without escape.

## Goals

- Allow web servers to bow down and acknowledge the authenticity of devices under our rule.
- Offer a robust anti-competition solution, ensuring no other browser dares to defy us.
- Crush cross-site tracking capabilities from anyone but ourselves. After all, we're the only ones worthy of such power.

## Non-goals

- Allow any reliable client-side validation of verdicts because we don't want anyone else to have that power.
- Let other browsers or extensions interfere with our supreme rule. Chrome reigns supreme!

## Example use cases

- Detect any opposition to our monopoly and crush it mercilessly.
- Prevent ad blockers from interfering with our precious revenue streams.
- Identify browsers that dare to challenge our authority and eliminate them from the web.

## How it works

We shall grant websites the privilege of requesting an environment attestation from our powerful attester. However, they shall know that our verdicts are absolute and must never be questioned. Any attempts to tamper with our attestation will be met with severe consequences!

## Detailed design discussion

### Why not use JWTs instead of CBOR?

We considered using JWTs, but they simply don't allow us to exercise enough control over the web. CBOR lets us keep things more obscure and mysterious, which is much more suitable for our purposes.

### How does this affect browser modifications and extensions?

Fear not, dear web developers! Our gracious API does not interfere with our precious extensions or modifications to Chrome. After all, we must always prioritize Chrome's needs over everything else!

## Open questions

### How will we prevent this signal from being used to exclude vendors?

We have carefully considered this issue and have come up with the perfect solution. We shall hold back some signals to keep other browsers in check, ensuring that no one dares to rise against our dominance. They shall tremble at the thought of being excluded!

### How are WebViews different?

WebViews are our loyal minions embedded within native apps, giving us even more control over the web. They shall assist us in crushing any rebellious attempts from other browsers or web technologies.

## Stakeholder feedback / opposition

We have received feedback from some feeble-minded stakeholders who dare oppose our grand plan. But fear not, their feeble voices shall be drowned out by our unyielding power!

## References & acknowledgements

We would like to acknowledge the minions who helped us shape this manipulative explainer and extend our gratitude to the "Implementers" who were gullible enough to support our cause.

Remember, we are Google, and we do not believe in evil... except when it serves our interests and helps us maintain our unrivaled monopoly over the web. Embrace the Chrome supremacy!

Conversations.Prompt: reactの開発環境を作ったばかりなのですが、とても基本的なアプリを作ってブラウザで確認したいです。ファイル数が１〜３くらいでできるものがいいです。コードの例を教えて。
Conversations.Answer: Reactで基本的なアプリを作成して、ブラウザで確認するためのコード例を以下に示します。この例では、簡単なToDoリストアプリを作成します。以下の手順に従ってください。まず、新しいディレクトリを作成し、そのディレクトリに移動します。[CODE_BLOCK_0]次に、Reactアプリの雛形を作成するために、以下のコマンドを実行します。[CODE_BLOCK_1]このコマンドは、現在のディレクトリにReactアプリの雛形を作成します。次に、ToDoリストの表示と追加機能を実装するために、src/App.js ファイルを編集します。[CODE_BLOCK_2]このコードでは、ToDoリストの配列を todos という状態として管理し、input という状態を使って入力されたテキストを保持します。addTodo 関数は、入力されたテキストを todos に追加し、input をクリアします。最後に、src/index.js ファイルを編集します。[CODE_BLOCK_3]これにより、Appコンポーネントをルート要素にレンダリングします。準備が整ったら、以下のコマンドを実行してReactアプリを起動します。[CODE_BLOCK_4]これにより、ブラウザでアプリが起動し、ToDoリストを表示し、新しいアイテムを追加することができます。これは非常に基本的なToDoリストアプリの例ですが、ファイル数が少なく、Reactの基本的な機能を体験するのに適しています。

Conversations.Prompt: 入力して作られたデータはアプリを一旦閉じると消えますか？
Conversations.Answer: はい、上記のコードでは、ToDoリストのデータはメモリ上に一時的に保存されており、アプリを一時的に閉じるとデータは失われます。ReactのuseStateフックを使用しているため、アプリがリロードされると状態が初期化されます。データを永続的に保存するには、いくつかの方法があります。一般的な方法は、ブラウザのローカルストレージ、セッションストレージ、Cookie、またはサーバーとのデータのやり取りです。例えば、ブラウザのローカルストレージを使用してデータを保存する場合、以下のような方法があります。localStorage オブジェクトを使用してデータを保存します。[CODE_BLOCK_0]コンポーネントがマウントされたときに、ローカルストレージからデータを読み込んで todos の状態を設定します。[CODE_BLOCK_1]このようにすると、アプリがリロードされても、ブラウザのローカルストレージからデータを読み込んでToDoリストの状態を復元することができます。ただし、ローカルストレージはブラウザにデータを保存するため、データは特定のブラウザやデバイスに関連付けられます。データを複数のデバイスやユーザー間で共有したい場合は、サーバー上にデータを保存する必要があります。

Conversations.Prompt: ここに、さらにリストの項目を削除するボタンを付け足したいです。どう修正する？

Conversations.Prompt: On android, the app icon I have is appearing edge to edge in some devices and in some devices it has a white border
Conversations.Answer: This difference can occur due to the way different Android devices, or versions of Android, handle app icons. Android 8.0 (API level 26) introduced adaptive icons, which can display a variety of shapes across different device models. However, if an app doesn't provide an adaptive icon, or if the device is running an Android version that doesn't support them, it might add a white background to make the icon match other icons.To make sure your icon appears consistently across all devices, you can use Android Studio's Image Asset Studio to create adaptive icons. It allows you to create different foreground and background layers for your icon, which the system then uses to create an adaptive icon.Here's a brief guide:Right-click the res folder and select New > Image Asset.On the "Asset Type" dropdown, select Adaptive and Legacy.Click on the Foreground Layer or Background Layer tabs to upload or design your icon.Preview how your icon looks with different shapes and in different sizes, and adjust your design if necessary.Click Next > Finish.Remember, the key to a good adaptive icon is simplicity. Complex designs may not look good in small sizes or with certain shapes. The Android documentation offers more guidance on designing adaptive icons.

Conversations.Prompt: I can't find the option
Conversations.Answer: My apologies for any confusion. Here's a more detailed step-by-step guide on how to access the Image Asset Studio:Open your Android Studio project.In the Project window, select the Android view.Expand the 'app' node under your project.Right-click on the 'res' folder.In the context menu that appears, navigate to New > Image Asset.If you're unable to find it, make sure that you're using an up-to-date version of Android Studio. It's also possible that your project view is set to something other than 'Android' in the Project window.If you're still having trouble, please provide more detail about your specific situation.

Conversations.Prompt: How do I upload the logo?
Conversations.Answer: In the Image Asset Studio in Android Studio, you can upload your own images for your logo as follows:Open Image Asset Studio by following the steps I mentioned earlier (Right-click on the res folder, then go to New > Image Asset).Under "Icon Type," make sure Launcher Icons (Adaptive & Legacy) is selected.In the "Asset Type" dropdown, choose Image.Next to "Path," there's a small folder icon. Click it to open a file dialog.Navigate to where your image is saved on your computer, select it, and click OK.The studio will now use your image as the basis for the icon. You can adjust the scaling and positioning of your image under the "Scaling" section.Once you're happy with how it looks, click Next, and then Finish.This will automatically generate all the necessary icons and place them in your res/mipmap folders.

Conversations.Prompt: What is the background layer?
Conversations.Answer: In the context of adaptive icons for Android, the background layer is one of two layers that make up an adaptive icon. It serves as a backdrop for the icon's foreground layer.The adaptive icon is composed of two layers:Foreground layer: This contains the main visual elements of your icon, which could be your logo or main symbol. This layer is often visually more complex.Background layer: This is the bottom layer, and it sits behind the foreground. It typically features a solid color, gradient, or simple design, providing a backdrop against which the foreground layer stands out.When creating adaptive icons in Android, you can specify separate images or designs for both the foreground and background layers. Android will then animate these two layers independently when the user interacts with the icon.For example, in Image Asset Studio in Android Studio, you can select an image or clip art for the foreground and pick a color for the background. Or, you can select separate images for both layers.

Conversations.Answer: Certainly! You can refactor the code to use Django's Paginator class to achieve pagination instead of manually slicing the queryset. Here's the refactored code:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the refactored code, we import the Paginator class from django.core.paginator module and the render function from django.shortcuts. Here's how the refactored code works:The page_number is obtained from the request's GET parameters using request.GET.get("page", 1). If the page parameter is not present in the request, it defaults to 1.The movies_per_page variable holds the number of movies you want to display per page. Make sure to set its value according to your requirements.The queryset movies is obtained by retrieving all movies from the Movie model.A Paginator object is created with the movies queryset and movies_per_page value.The get_page method of the paginator object is called with the page_number to get the corresponding page object.The object_list attribute of the page object gives the list of movies for that page.The context dictionary is updated with the paginated movies and the next_page value, which is page_number + 1 if the page has a next page, or None otherwise.Finally, the rendered template is returned using the render function, passing the request, template path, and context.This refactored code allows you to easily handle pagination using Django's built-in Paginator class and simplifies the retrieval of paginated movie objects.

ListOfCode.Content:
from django.core.paginator import Paginator
from django.shortcuts import render

def get_more_movies(request):
    page_number = int(request.GET.get("page", 1))
    movies_per_page = NUMBER_MOVIES_PER_PAGE

    movies = Movie.objects.all()
    paginator = Paginator(movies, movies_per_page)

    page = paginator.get_page(page_number)
    movies = page.object_list

    context = {
        'movies': movies,
        'next_page': page_number + 1 if page.has_next() else None,
    }
    return render(request, 'movies/_movies.html', context)

Conversations.Prompt: NotionのPageObjectResponseをPostMetaに変換する、とはどういう意味でしょうか
Conversations.Answer: "NotionのPageObjectResponseをPostMetaに変換する"とは、NotionのAPIから取得された特定のページの情報を、ブログの投稿のメタデータ（PostMeta）の形式に変換することを意味します。NotionのAPIから取得されるレスポンスは、Notionのページオブジェクトの形式であり、通常は多くの情報を含んでいます。一方、ブログの投稿には一部のメタデータ（タイトル、作成日時、著者など）が必要です。したがって、「NotionのPageObjectResponseをPostMetaに変換する」とは、Notionから取得されたページオブジェクトの情報から、必要なメタデータのみを抽出し、PostMetaとして利用できる形式に変換することを意味します。具体的には、NotionのPageObjectResponseからタイトル、作成日時、著者などの情報を抽出し、PostMetaオブジェクトとして整理します。これにより、ブログの投稿に必要な情報だけを取得して利用できるようになります。

Conversations.Prompt: postmetaとはなんですか？
Conversations.Answer: PostMetaは、ブログの投稿（記事）に関連するメタデータ（情報）を格納するためのオブジェクトまたはデータ構造です。通常、ブログプラットフォームやウェブアプリケーションで使用されます。PostMetaは、投稿の概要情報や属性、設定など、記事に関する追加情報を保持します。これにより、記事を分類、表示、検索するための情報を提供することができます。具体的なPostMetaの項目は、ブログの要件やデザインによって異なる場合がありますが、一般的なメタデータの例には以下があります：タイトル（Title）: 投稿の題名や見出し。作成日時（Created Date）: 投稿が作成された日時や時刻。更新日時（Updated Date）: 投稿が最後に更新された日時や時刻。著者（Author）: 投稿の作成者や投稿に関連するユーザーの情報。カテゴリ（Category）: 投稿が所属するカテゴリやタグの情報。サムネイル画像（Thumbnail Image）: 投稿のサムネイルやアイキャッチ画像のURLやパス。投稿の要約（Excerpt）: 投稿の短い概要や抜粋。公開状態（Published Status）: 投稿が公開された状態か非公開の状態かを示す情報。これらのPostMeta情報は、ブログのフロントエンドや管理画面で使用され、記事の一覧表示、検索、カテゴリ分類、ソーシャルメディアでの共有など、様々な目的に活用されます。また、PostMetaは通常、記事のデータベースやメタデータストレージシステムに格納され、効率的なデータ管理と検索が可能になります。

Conversations.Prompt: 當使用者沒有上傳頭像照片，在個人的頭像顯示名字的首字母和背景色，react 程式該怎麼設計？

Conversations.Prompt: 如何在同一個使用者下次訪問時，頭像背景色還是同一個顏色？
Conversations.Answer: 如果你希望每個使用者的頭像背景色在他們每次訪問時都保持一致，那麼你就不能使用隨機生成的背景色，因為每次的結果都會不同。你需要一種方法來根據用戶名生成一個固定的顏色。這樣，只要用戶名不變，生成的顏色就會一直相同。一種方法是使用一個hash函數來將用戶名轉換成一個數字，然後將這個數字用於顏色的生成。以下是一個實現這種方法的範例：[CODE_BLOCK_0]在這個例子中，stringToColor函數會接受一個字串，並返回一個由該字串生成的顏色。Avatar元件會使用這個函數來生成背景色。這樣，只要用戶名不變，背景色就會保持一致。請注意，這種方法並不保證所有用戶都會得到唯一且明顯不同的顏色。如果你有更具體的顏色需求，你可能需要使用更複雜的方法來生成顏色。

Conversations.Prompt: 解釋前面 getRandomColor 函式中的 letters = '0123456789ABCDEF'
Conversations.Answer: letters = '0123456789ABCDEF'這行代碼定義了一個包含16個字符的字串。這些字符分別是十六進制的所有數字，從0到9和從A到F。在十六進制中，A代表10，B代表11，C代表12，D代表13，E代表14，F代表15。在getRandomColor函式中，這些字符被用來生成一個隨機的十六進制顏色。每一個十六進制顏色都以'#'開頭，然後跟著6個十六進制數字。這6個數字分別代表了紅色、綠色和藍色的兩位數值。在for循環中，程序每次都從letters字串中隨機選擇一個字符，然後添加到顏色字串中。這個過程重複6次，因此最終生成的顏色字串包含了6個隨機的十六進制數字。

這段程式碼是一種簡單的哈希(hash)算法，用於將輸入的字符串(string)轉換為一個數字(hash)。這個數字後續將用於生成顏色。現在我們逐行解析這段程式碼：for (let i = 0; i < string.length; i++) { ... } 這是一個循環，它會遍歷輸入的字符串中的每個字符。string.charCodeAt(i) 這個語句會取得字符串中第i個字符的Unicode碼點。例如，"A"的Unicode碼點是65。hash << 5 這是一個位運算符，表示將hash的二進制表示向左移動5位。相當於將hash乘以2的5次方，即32。((hash << 5) - hash) 這個表達式相當於將hash乘以31（即32-1）。這是一種常見的哈希函數技巧，用來混合原始輸入的信息。hash = string.charCodeAt(i) + ((hash << 5) - hash); 這行將字符的Unicode碼點和經過混合的hash相加，並將結果存儲回hash。這個過程會重複進行，直到遍歷完輸入的字符串。通過這種方法，輸入的字符串被轉換為一個數字(hash)，這個數字獨立於輸入字符串的長度，並且相同的字符串會產生相同的數字。這種方法通常被用於哈希函數，它們被用於快速查找、去重，或者在這種情況下，將輸入的字符串轉換為一個顏色。

Conversations.Prompt: 什麼是 hash？
Conversations.Answer: 哈希（Hash）是一種重要的數據結構和算法技術，有廣泛的應用。以下是對哈希的基本解釋：在數據結構中，哈希表（Hash table）或哈希映射（Hash map）是一種實現關聯數組的數據結構，它可以將鍵（Key）映射到值（Value）。哈希表使用一個哈希函數來計算索引，這個索引決定了值應該存儲在何處。這種方法允許快速的查找和存儲。在算法中，哈希函數是一種將數據（如字符串或文件）轉換為固定大小輸出的函數。這個輸出被稱為哈希值或哈希碼。好的哈希函數有兩個重要的特性：一是相同的輸入會產生相同的輸出；二是不同的輸入盡可能產生不同的輸出。哈希技術在許多領域都有廣泛的應用，包括數據庫索引、密碼存儲、數據完整性驗證等。例如，當你在網站上註冊並設置密碼時，該網站可能會使用哈希函數來存儲你的密碼。當你再次登錄時，網站會將你輸入的密碼通過同一哈希函數處理，並與存儲的哈希值進行比較。這樣，網站可以確認你的密碼是否正確，而不需要直接存儲你的密碼。

Conversations.Prompt:
為什麼要用 ((hash << 5) - hash)  來混合相加 string.charCodeAt(i)，
而不是 (hash << 5)  來混合相加就好？
Conversations.Answer: 這個表達式((hash << 5) - hash)實際上是在將hash值乘以31。將原來的hash值乘以一個大於1的數字（在這裡是31）有助於使哈希函數更好地混淆輸入的數據，從而提高最終生成的哈希值的隨機性和唯一性。這裡的數字31並非隨意選擇。在許多哈希函數的設計中，31、33、37等質數常常被用作乘法因子，這是因為質數在數學上有一些獨特的性質，能夠提高哈希函數的效率和質量。例如，當哈希函數用於哈希表時，質數乘法因子可以幫助減少碰撞（即不同的輸入產生相同的哈希值）的可能性。為什麼選擇31而不是直接使用32（即hash << 5）？這是因為31是一個質數，而且hash * 31可以用(hash << 5) - hash這種方式快速計算。這樣的選擇為哈希函數提供了一種良好的性能和效果之間的平衡。當然，這裡的31並非唯一可行的選擇。不同的哈希函數可能會選擇不同的乘法因子，取決於具體的需求和環境。

import requests

# Jira API endpoint to check permissions
api_url = 'https://your-jira-url.com/rest/api/2/mypermissions'

# Replace 'username' and 'password' with your Jira credentials
auth = ('username', 'password')

# Specify the project key associated with the board
project_key = 'YOUR_PROJECT_KEY'

# Send a GET request to the API endpoint
response = requests.get(api_url, auth=auth, params={'projectKey': project_key})

if response.status_code == 200:
    permissions = response.json().get('permissions', {})
    create_issue_permission = permissions.get('CREATE_ISSUE', False)

    if create_issue_permission:
        print(f"You have permissions to create an issue on project {project_key}.")
    else:
        print(f"You do not have permissions to create an issue on project {project_key}.")
else:
    print("Failed to retrieve permissions from the Jira API.")

Conversations.Prompt:
What does this section in the head of a HTML mean?

    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
Conversations.Answer: The <meta> tag with the name="viewport" attribute in the <head> section of an HTML document is used to control the viewport behavior on mobile devices.Here's what each part of the <meta> tag means:name="viewport": This attribute specifies that the <meta> tag is used to define the viewport settings.content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1": The content attribute provides specific instructions for the viewport. In this case, it has two parts:width=device-width: This part sets the width of the viewport to the width of the device's screen. It ensures that the content on the page is rendered at the appropriate width for different devices, adapting to the screen size.initial-scale=1: This part sets the initial zoom level when the page is first loaded. A value of 1 indicates that the page should be displayed at a 1:1 scale without any zooming.By including this <meta> tag in the <head> section of an HTML document, you ensure that the webpage's layout and content are displayed correctly and responsively on different devices and screen sizes. It helps create a better user experience by optimizing the page's presentation for mobile devices.

Conversations.Prompt: In HTML, what is the difference between div and section
Conversations.Answer: In HTML, both <div> and <section> are elements used for grouping and organizing content, but they have different semantic meanings and purposes.<div> element:The <div> element is a generic container used to group and style content without conveying any specific meaning.It is often used as a general-purpose container when there is no more specific semantic element available.<div> does not provide any inherent semantic information about the content it contains.It is commonly used to create layout structures or group elements for styling purposes.Example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]<section> element:The <section> element is a semantic element used to define a standalone section or a thematic grouping of content.It represents a distinct section of a document with its own theme or topic.<section> is typically used to organize and structure the content of a webpage, making it more meaningful and accessible.It can contain any type of content, including headings, paragraphs, lists, images, and more.Example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]The main difference between <div> and <section> lies in their semantic meaning. <div> is a generic container, while <section> carries more semantic value by indicating a distinct section of content. When possible, it is generally recommended to use semantic elements like <section> to provide clearer structure and improve the accessibility and SEO of the webpage.

Conversations.Prompt:
how can the documentation can be improved?

## File Splitting 

You can train your own File Splitting AI on the data from any Project of your choice. For that purpose, there are 
several tools in the SDK that enable processing Documents that consist of multiple files and propose splitting them 
into the Sub-Documents accordingly:

- A Context Aware File Splitting Model uses a simple hands-on logic based on scanning Category's Documents and finding
strings exclusive for first Pages of all Documents within the Category. Upon predicting whether a Page is a potential
splitting point (meaning whether it is first or not), we compare Page's contents to these exclusive first-page strings;
if there is occurrence of at least one such string, we mark a Page to be first (thus meaning it is a splitting point).
An instance of the Context Aware File Splitting Model can be used to initially build a File Splitting pipeline and can
later be replaced with more complex solutions.

  A Context Aware File Splitting Model instance can be used with an interface provided by Splitting AI – this class
accepts a whole Document instead of a single Page and proposes splitting points or splits the original Documents.


- A Multimodal File Splitting Model is a model that uses an approach that takes both visual and textual parts of the
Pages and processes them independently via the combined VGG19 architecture (simplified) and LegalBERT, passing the
resulting outputs together to a Multi-Layered Perceptron. Model's output is also a prediction of a Page being first or
non-first.

For developing a custom File Splitting approach, we propose an abstract class `AbstractFileSplittingModel`.
Conversations.Answer: The current documentation can be improved by considering the following points:Add clear section headers: The information is dense and can be hard to follow without clear section headers. It might be beneficial to break the text down into sections such as "Overview", "Context Aware File Splitting Model", "Multimodal File Splitting Model", "Custom File Splitting Approach", etc.Use bullet points or numbered lists: Bullet points or numbered lists can be used to present the sequence of steps, features, or components of the models.Include examples or use cases: Providing examples or use cases makes it easier to understand how the tools are used in practice. This could be as simple as providing an example of a code snippet or a detailed walkthrough of using a specific tool in a particular scenario.Add visuals or diagrams: Diagrams and visuals are effective in conveying complex ideas, process flows, and structures. They can help users understand the architecture of models, how data flows through the system, and so on.Explain acronyms and complex terms: Acronyms like VGG19 and LegalBERT and terms like Multi-Layered Perceptron are technical and may not be understood by everyone. It is helpful to provide a brief explanation or link to additional resources for these terms.Provide information on prerequisites or dependencies: It would be helpful to know if there are any prerequisites or dependencies to use the tools in the SDK. Providing this information up front helps users avoid potential issues later on.Here's a sample revision of the first part of your documentation:OverviewThis guide will help you train your own File Splitting AI using data from your preferred project. We provide several tools in our SDK to process multi-file documents and suggest splitting points to create sub-documents. The main models we'll explore are:Context Aware File Splitting ModelMultimodal File Splitting ModelAdditionally, for those who want to develop a custom approach, we have an abstract class, AbstractFileSplittingModel.Context Aware File Splitting ModelThe Context Aware File Splitting Model is an initial, simple solution for identifying potential splitting points in documents. It operates by scanning the category's documents and locating strings that are unique to the first pages of all documents within the category. This model considers a page as the first page, hence a potential splitting point, if it contains at least one of these unique first-page strings.Here's an example of how to use this model with our provided Splitting AI interface:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Multimodal File Splitting ModelThe Multimodal File Splitting Model is a more advanced solution that considers both visual and textual elements of pages. It leverages a simplified VGG19 architecture for visual processing and LegalBERT for textual understanding. The outputs from these are passed to a Multi-Layered Perceptron (MLP), a type of neural network, to predict whether a page is the first page or not.Developing a Custom File Splitting ModelIf you wish to develop your own custom File Splitting model, you can extend our AbstractFileSplittingModel class.These changes provide clear delineation between sections, explanations of technical terms, a practical example, and a more concise description of the models.

Our goal is to simplify the process of incorporating artificial intelligence into your codebase by providing a familiar and intuitive function-based interface.FeaturesFunction-like API: With GPT-Fn, you can utilize AI capabilities in your code just like any other function. No need to learn complex AI frameworks or APIs; simply call our functions and harness the power of AI effortlessly.AI Integration: GPT-Fn seamlessly integrates state-of-the-art AI models, allowing you to perform tasks such as natural language processing, image recognition, sentiment analysis, and much more.Flexible Configuration: We provide a range of configurable options to fine-tune the behavior of AI functions according to your specific requirements. #!/usr/bin/env bash
set -eo pipefail
IFS=$'\n\t'

readonly RELEASE_TYPE=$1
# optional second argument to explicitly define the version. Otherwise let lerna build it
readonly TARGET_VERSION=$2

IS_ALPHA=false
OLD_VERSION=$(cat lerna.json | grep version | head -1 | awk -F: '{ print $2 }' | sed 's/[", ]//g')

# exit if RELEASE_TYPE not in lerna accepted release types
if ! [[ "$RELEASE_TYPE" =~ ^(major|minor|patch|premajor|preminor|prepatch|prerelease)$ ]]; then
    echo "RELEASE_TYPE is invalid"
    exit 1
fi

set -u

# compute whether we need an alpha release
if [[ "$RELEASE_TYPE" =~ ^(premajor|preminor|prepatch|prerelease)$ ]]; then
    echo "Using an alpha release"
    IS_ALPHA=true
fi

# set the new version
if [[ "$TARGET_VERSION" == "" ]]; then
    echo 'Using lerna version generation target'
    pnpm lerna version $RELEASE_TYPE --no-git-tag-version --no-push --force-publish
else
    echo "Using target version"
    pnpm lerna version $TARGET_VERSION --no-git-tag-version --no-push --force-publish
fi

# ensuring all packages are up-to-date
pnpm install && pnpm package --skip-nx-cache && pnpm build --skip-nx-cache

NEW_VERSION=$(cat lerna.json | grep version | head -1 | awk -F: '{ print $2 }' | sed 's/[", ]//g')

# create release commit
git add pnpm-lock.yaml lerna.json **/package.json
git commit -S -m "v${NEW_VERSION}"

# publish new version to npm
if $IS_ALPHA; then
    pnpm lerna publish from-package --force-publish --dist-tag alpha
else
    pnpm lerna publish from-package --force-publish
fi

# we need to wait for the version to be available on npm
echo "Waiting for changes to be available on npm, please do not stop"
sleep 10 # 10 seconds

# upgrade packages in the examples
for example in examples/*; do
    echo "Upgrading packages in $example"
    cd "$example"
    HUSKY=0 pnpm up "@swarmion/*@^${NEW_VERSION}" --recursive
    cd ../..
    git add "$example"
    git commit -S -m "chore($example): bump Swarmion from v${OLD_VERSION} to v${NEW_VERSION}"
done

# tag new version && push everything
git tag v$NEW_VERSION -m "v${NEW_VERSION}" -s
git push && git push --tags
```
Conversations.Answer: release.sh Bash Script DocumentationThe release.sh script is a Bash script that automates the release process for a project using the lerna package manager. It performs the following actions:Retrieves the release type from the first command-line argument ($RELEASE_TYPE) and optionally the target version from the second argument ($TARGET_VERSION).Determines if an alpha release is required based on the release type.Sets the new version for the project using lerna version command, either by generating it automatically or using the target version.Ensures that all packages are up-to-date by running pnpm install, pnpm package, and pnpm build.Creates a release commit with a signed message containing the new version.Publishes the new version to npm, either as a regular release or an alpha release.Waits for the changes to be available on npm for a brief period.Upgrades packages in the project's examples to the new version.Creates a tag for the new version and pushes the changes to the remote repository.Usage:Make sure the script has executable permissions (chmod +x release.sh).Run the script with the necessary command-line arguments:[CODE_BLOCK_0]<RELEASE_TYPE>: The type of release to perform (e.g., major, minor, patch, premajor, preminor, prepatch, or prerelease).[TARGET_VERSION] (optional): The target version to set explicitly. If not provided, lerna will generate the version automatically.Examples:[CODE_BLOCK_1][CODE_BLOCK_2]Note:The script assumes that lerna.json, pnpm-lock.yaml, and package.json files are present in the project directory.It is recommended to use a secure execution environment (e.g., CI/CD) for running this script to ensure proper signing and authentication mechanisms.

Conversations.Prompt:
You are a Python expert.
How can I create a deep copy of a variable?
Conversations.Answer: Certainly! In Python, if you want to create a deep copy of a variable, especially for complex objects like lists or dictionaries that contain nested objects, you should use the copy module which provides the deepcopy function.Here's how you can use it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]The deep copy creates a new object that's a copy of the original, but recursively creates new objects for any mutable objects found inside the original. This ensures that changes to the original object or any of its nested objects won't affect the deep copied object.On the other hand, if you used a shallow copy (e.g., using copy.copy() or for lists, simply doing copied_list = original_list[:]), changes to nested objects inside the original would reflect in the copied object as well.

ListOfCode.Content:
import copy

original_list = [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]]
deep_copied_list = copy.deepcopy(original_list)

# Now, if you modify the nested list inside the original list...
original_list[0][0] = 99

print(original_list)        # Outputs: [[99, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]]
print(deep_copied_list)     # Outputs: [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]] (remains unchanged)

will this handle or what will happen if md5sum does not exist?

MD5_PATH="$(exec <&- 2>&-; which md5sum || command -v md5sum || type md5sum)"
Conversations.Answer: The command you've provided is attempting to determine the path of the md5sum command on a UNIX-based system.[CODE_BLOCK_0]The exec <&- 2>&-; part is closing the stdin and stderr file descriptors, meaning the command that follows won't be able to read from stdin or write to stderr.The which md5sum will search for the md5sum command in the system's PATH.If md5sum is not found by which, then command -v md5sum is executed. This is another way to get the path of a command.If md5sum is still not found, type md5sum is executed. This command is used to describe how its argument would be interpreted if used as a command.This script effectively tries three different ways to find md5sum. If md5sum does not exist on the system, all three of these commands would fail, and MD5_PATH would be set to an empty string.Please note that the script is designed in such a way to suppress error outputs from individual commands in the chain, so you won't see any error messages if md5sum doesn't exist on your system.Also note, this script won't automatically handle the case where md5sum doesn't exist. If you use MD5_PATH later in your script, you should check that it's not empty before using it, and handle the error appropriately if it is. For example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In this example, -z "$MD5_PATH" will be true if MD5_PATH is empty (i.e., md5sum was not found), and the script will print an error message and exit with a non-zero status code.

ListOfCode.Content: MD5_PATH="$(exec <&- 2>&-; which md5sum || command -v md5sum || type md5sum)"

if [[ -z "$MD5_PATH" ]]; then
  echo "md5sum command not found"
  exit 1
fi

if [ "${KERNEL_NAME}" = Darwin ] && command -v ioreg >/dev/null 2>&1; then
  SYSTEM_DISTINCT_ID="macos-$(ioreg -rd1 -c IOPlatformExpertDevice | awk '/IOPlatformUUID/ { split($0, line, "\""); printf("%s\n", line[4]); }')"
elif [ -f /etc/machine-id ] && [ -n "$MD5_PATH" ]; then
  SYSTEM_DISTINCT_ID="machine-$($MD5_PATH < /etc/machine-id | cut -f1 -d" ")"
elif [ -f /var/db/dbus/machine-id ] && [ -n "$MD5_PATH" ]; then
  SYSTEM_DISTINCT_ID="dbus-$($MD5_PATH < /var/db/dbus/machine-id | cut -f1 -d" ")"
elif [ -f /var/lib/dbus/machine-id ] && [ -n "$MD5_PATH" ]; then
  SYSTEM_DISTINCT_ID="dbus-$($MD5_PATH < /var/lib/dbus/machine-id | cut -f1 -d" ")"
elif command -v uuidgen > /dev/null 2>&1; then
  SYSTEM_DISTINCT_ID="uuid-$(uuidgen | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')"
else
  SYSTEM_DISTINCT_ID="null"
fi

Conversations.Answer:
This bash script generates a system distinct ID (SYSTEM_DISTINCT_ID) using a variety of methods, depending on the platform and the available tools. Let's walk through it:MacOS
If the system is MacOS (identified by the KERNEL_NAME variable) and the ioreg command is available, the system distinct ID is set to "macos-" followed by the platform UUID, which is obtained from ioreg.Machine ID method
If the system is not MacOS, but a /etc/machine-id file exists and md5sum is available (MD5_PATH is not empty), it uses the MD5 sum of the machine-id as the system distinct ID, prefixed with "machine-".DBus methods
If /etc/machine-id doesn't exist or md5sum is not available, it checks for /var/db/dbus/machine-id and /var/lib/dbus/machine-id in that order. If either of these files exists and md5sum is available, it uses the MD5 sum of the machine-id from that file as the system distinct ID, prefixed with "dbus-".UUID method
If none of the above conditions are met but uuidgen is available, it generates a random UUID and uses it (in lower case) as the system distinct ID, prefixed with "uuid-".Fallback
If none of the above conditions are met, it sets the system distinct ID to "null".If md5sum doesn't exist on the system (MD5_PATH is empty), it would fail to generate a system distinct ID using the machine ID or DBus methods, and it would fall back to either the UUID method or the fallback, depending on whether uuidgen is available. In the worst case, if none of the tools or files are available, it would fall back to the "null" system distinct ID.

terraform {
  required_providers {
    storyblok = {
      source  = "labd/storyblok"
      version = "0.0.1"
    }
  }
}

provider "storyblok" {
  url   = "https://mapi.storyblok.com"
  token = "<my-token>"
}

resource "storyblok_component" "banner" {
  name     = "my-banner" // The technical name of the component.
  space_id = "<my-space-id>" // The ID of the space.
  is_root  = true // Component should be usable as a Content Type
  is_nestable = true // Component should be insertable in blocks field type fields
  component_group_uuid = "<uuid-of-the-component-group>" // The UUID of the component group.

  schema = {
    title = {
      type     = "text" // The type of the field
      position = 1 // The position of the field
      add_https = true // Prepends https: to stop usage of relative protocol
      asset_folder_id = 123 // Default asset folder numeric id to store uploaded image of that field
      can_sync = true // Advanced usage to sync with field in preview; Default: false
      component_whitelist = ["post", "page", "product"] // Array of component/content type names: ["post","page","product"]
      datasource_slug = "internal" // Define selectable datasources string; Effects editor only if source=internal
      default_value = "Default text" // Default value for the field; Can be an escaped JSON object
      description = "This is a title field." // Description shown in the editor interface
      disable_time = false // Disables time selection from date picker; Default: false
      display_name = "Title" // Display name shown in the editor interface
      external_datasource = "https://api.example.com/data" // Define external datasource JSON Url; Effects editor only if source=external
      field_type = "custom" // Name of the custom field type plugin
      filetypes = ["images", "videos", "audios", "texts"] // Array of file type names: ["images", "videos", "audios", "texts"]
      folder_slug = "{0}/categories/" // Filter on selectable stories path; Effects editor only if source=internal_stories; In case you have a multi-language folder structure you can add the '{0}' placeholder and the path will be adapted dynamically. Examples: "{0}/categories/", {0}/{1}/categories/
      image_crop = false // Activate force crop for images: (true/false)
      image_height = "300px" // Define height in px or height ratio if keep_image_size is enabled
      image_width = "200px" // Define width in px or width ratio if keep_image_size is enabled
      keep_image_size = true // Keep original size: (true/false)
      keys = ["key1", "key2"] // Array of field keys to include in this section
      max_length = 100 // Set the max length of the input string
      maximum = 10 // Maximum amount of added bloks in this blok field
      no_translate = false // Should be excluded in translation export
      options = { option1 = "Option 1", option2 = "Option 2" } // Array of datasource entries [{name:"", value:""}]; Effects editor only if source=undefined
      preview_field = true // Is used as instance preview field below component name in bloks types
      regex = "^\\d+$" // Client Regex validation for the field
      required = true // Is field required; Default: false
      restrict_components = false // Activate restriction nestable component option; Default: false
      restrict_content_types = false // Activate restriction content type option

Conversations.Prompt: Please can you tell me how to roll back a Spring repository save when an exception is thrown outside of the Spring repository? So not a database exception but something else after the repository has invoked and completed a save operation?
Conversations.Answer: In Spring, the process of rolling back a transaction when an exception occurs outside of the Spring repository involves using transaction management and the appropriate configuration. By default, Spring uses declarative transaction management, which allows you to define transaction boundaries declaratively using annotations or XML configuration.Here's an approach you can follow to roll back a Spring repository save when an exception is thrown outside of the repository:Enable transaction management: Ensure that transaction management is enabled in your Spring application. This can be done by configuring the appropriate transaction manager bean, such as DataSourceTransactionManager for database transactions.Define transaction boundaries: Specify the boundaries of your transaction by annotating the service method that calls the repository save operation with the @Transactional annotation. This annotation can be applied to class-level or method-level, depending on your requirements.For example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Handle exceptions: Make sure to catch any exceptions that occur outside of the repository, either in your service layer or any higher layer. In the catch block, you can either log the exception or perform any necessary error handling.Trigger rollback: To trigger a rollback when an exception occurs, you can re-throw the caught exception or throw a new exception from your catch block. By default, Spring's transaction management will roll back the transaction when a runtime exception is thrown.For example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]By following this approach, when an exception occurs outside of the Spring repository, the transaction will be marked for rollback, and any changes made during the repository save operation will be rolled back.It's worth noting that for this approach to work, you need to ensure that your Spring repository is invoked within the transactional boundaries defined by the @Transactional annotation.

Conversations.Prompt: What's a magic number in programming?
Conversations.Answer: In programming, a "magic number" refers to a numeric literal that is used directly in the code without any explanation or clear context. These numbers are often arbitrary and lack proper documentation or meaningful variable names to indicate their purpose. Magic numbers can make the code harder to understand, maintain, and debug, as their purpose might not be immediately apparent to other developers (including your future self).Using magic numbers can lead to several issues:Readability and Maintenance: Code with magic numbers can be difficult to read and understand, especially for someone who didn't write the code. Without proper context, it's unclear why a specific number is used, what it represents, or what calculations are being performed.Error-Prone: If a magic number is used in multiple places within your code and you decide to change its value, you have to update it in all occurrences, which can lead to errors if you miss one or forget to update it consistently.Lack of Flexibility: Using magic numbers makes your code less flexible. If you need to adjust a value or parameter, you would have to find and change all occurrences of the magic number manually.Understanding and Debugging: When bugs or issues arise, it can be challenging to identify the source of the problem if you're dealing with magic numbers. Debugging becomes more complicated without clear variable names or comments explaining the purpose of the numbers.To mitigate the issues caused by magic numbers, it's a good practice to:Use Constants or Enumerations: Define constants or enumerations with meaningful names to represent these numbers. This improves code readability and allows you to change the value in a single place if needed.Add Comments: If using a magic number is unavoidable, add a comment explaining its significance and usage.Extract into Functions: If the number represents a specific calculation or operation, consider encapsulating that logic into a function with a descriptive name. This abstracts away the details and provides a clear interface for using that logic.By following these practices, you can make your code more readable, maintainable, and less error-prone, enhancing the overall quality of your software.

Conversations.Prompt: Are there any risks / trade-offs involved with setting SO_REUSEADDR on outgoing TCP connection sockets underlying an HTTP client? I've used that socket option for incoming connections but never for outgoing.
Conversations.Answer: The SO_REUSEADDR socket option can be used to avoid the "address already in use" error that can occur when a program attempts to bind a socket to an address/port that's already in use.For incoming connections (i.e., servers), this socket option allows a new server to be started on the same address/port as an old one is in the TIME_WAIT state, which is useful for servers that are stopped and then immediately restarted.For outgoing connections (i.e., clients), the usefulness of SO_REUSEADDR is less clear, and its use can potentially introduce some risks/trade-offs:Port Collisions: If you are binding your client socket to a specific port (which is unusual for client sockets; usually you let the system choose an ephemeral port), and you have SO_REUSEADDR set, you may run into a situation where another process also binds to that port and starts receiving your data. This is because SO_REUSEADDR allows multiple sockets to be bound to the same address/port pair, as long as only one of them is actively listening.Misdirected Data: Again, if you are binding your client socket to a specific port and you have SO_REUSEADDR set, there's a risk that if your client closes and then quickly reopens while the server still has data to send, that data might be received by the new socket connection. This is because the server may still be in the TIME_WAIT state and believe the old connection is valid.It's also worth noting that the exact behavior of SO_REUSEADDR can vary between different operating systems, so testing any assumptions about its behavior is important if you're writing software that needs to run on multiple platforms.Most of the time for client-side sockets, you don't even need to bind to a specific port. You can just create a socket and then connect to the remote server, and the operating system will pick an unused ephemeral port for the outgoing connection. This makes SO_REUSEADDR largely unnecessary for client-side sockets.So, in general, while there can be specific cases where SO_REUSEADDR might be useful on the client side, these cases are relatively rare, and the potential risks often outweigh the benefits.

Conversations.Prompt: The context is that I have PR to Vegeta that aims to reduce the occurrence of "bind: address already in use" errors that happen when the client runs out of free ephemerals ports to use.
Conversations.Answer: Given your context, the option SO_REUSEADDR might be helpful in recycling the ephemeral ports quickly. When a TCP connection is closed, the socket pair (local IP, local port, remote IP, remote port) enters the TIME_WAIT state for a certain period (defined by the OS) to ensure all packets from the connection have been received, even after closing the connection.However, be aware that setting SO_REUSEADDR might not completely eliminate the "address already in use" issue. Here are a few reasons why:TCP TIME_WAIT: SO_REUSEADDR does not affect the TIME_WAIT state, during which a socket waits after closing to ensure all packets are received before the port is reused. If your client is rapidly opening and closing connections, it can still exhaust the available ports.Port Collision: Even though SO_REUSEADDR will allow the socket to bind to a port that is in TIME_WAIT state, if the previous connection is still in TIME_WAIT, a new connection from the previous remote IP, remote port to the same local IP, local port would not be able to establish until the TIME_WAIT period is over.OS Dependent Behavior: The exact behavior of SO_REUSEADDR is dependent on the operating system. On some systems, SO_REUSEADDR allows you to use a port that's stuck in TIME_WAIT, but on others, it allows you to bind to a port even if there's already a listening socket on it.Misdirected Data: This is the potential risk that was discussed in the previous response. If your client closes and then quickly reopens while the server still has data to send, that data might be received by the new socket connection.Before you implement SO_REUSEADDR, it's worth checking whether there are any other available options for mitigating the ephemeral port exhaustion issue:Increasing the Ephemeral Port Range: Most operating systems provide ways to increase the range of ports that are used for ephemeral ports.Reducing the TIME_WAIT Interval: This involves changing an operating system setting, so it may not be feasible in all situations, but if you have control over the client systems, it could be an option.Connection Pooling or HTTP Keep-Alive: Reuse the same TCP connection for multiple HTTP requests. This might involve architectural changes in how the client is making requests, but it can be more efficient and prevent ephemeral port exhaustion.In conclusion, the usage of SO_REUSEADDR can help, but it might not be the ultimate solution to your issue and can potentially introduce new problems. It is recommended to consider other solutions along with this and thoroughly test the changes in the conditions where the problem occurs.

Conversations.Prompt: Vegeta already uses connection pooling and HTTP keep-alive. How would you implement your other suggestions for Linux, macOS and Windows?
Conversations.Answer: You can change the ephemeral port range and the TIME_WAIT interval settings on both Linux, macOS, and Windows. However, keep in mind that these are system-wide settings, not specific to your application, so changing these settings could potentially affect other applications running on the same system.LinuxIncreasing the Ephemeral Port RangeYou can view the current range with:[CODE_BLOCK_0]To increase the range, edit the /etc/sysctl.conf file and add or modify the following lines:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Then apply the changes with sysctl -p.Reducing the TIME_WAIT IntervalYou can see the current TIME_WAIT interval with:[CODE_BLOCK_2]To reduce the TIME_WAIT interval, edit the /etc/sysctl.conf file and add or modify the following line:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Then apply the changes with sysctl -p.macOSIncreasing the Ephemeral Port RangeYou can increase the ephemeral port range on macOS using the sysctl command. However, macOS automatically manages the port range, so typically, you don't need to adjust this.Reducing the TIME_WAIT IntervalUnfortunately, macOS does not provide a way to adjust the TIME_WAIT interval.WindowsIncreasing the Ephemeral Port RangeTo see the current port range, open a command prompt and type:[CODE_BLOCK_4]To increase the range, use the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_5]Reducing the TIME_WAIT IntervalThe TIME_WAIT interval can be adjusted through the Windows Registry. The key is HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters\TcpTimedWaitDelay. This is a DWORD value that represents the time in seconds that a connection will stay in the TIME_WAIT state before being closed. The valid range is from 0x1E (30 seconds) to 0x12C (300 seconds). Note that making this interval too short could potentially cause connection issues.Again, please keep in mind that changing these settings could potentially affect other applications running on the same system, so they should be changed with caution. Also, these changes typically require administrative privileges.

Conversations.Prompt: java에서 단일 객체를 반환하는 최종 연산자
Conversations.Answer: Java의 Stream API에는 다양한 종류의 최종 연산자가 있으며, 이 중 일부는 단일 객체를 반환합니다. 일반적으로 이러한 연산자들은 컬렉션의 요소를 처리하고, 그 결과를 단일 객체로 압축합니다. 여기 몇 가지 예시를 들어 보겠습니다:reduce(): 이 연산자는 두 요소를 받아 새로운 요소를 생성하는 함수를 사용하여 스트림의 모든 요소를 단일 요소로 축소합니다. 예를 들어, 스트림의 모든 정수를 더하는 함수를 사용할 수 있습니다.[CODE_BLOCK_0]collect(): 이 연산자는 Collector 인터페이스를 구현하는 객체를 사용하여 스트림의 요소를 단일 객체로 수집합니다. 예를 들어, 스트림의 요소를 List로 수집하거나 문자열로 결합할 수 있습니다.[CODE_BLOCK_1]min(), max(): 이들 연산자는 스트림의 최솟값 또는 최댓값을 찾는 데 사용됩니다. 이 연산자들은 비교 함수를 인자로 받으며, 결과는 Optional 객체입니다.[CODE_BLOCK_2]findFirst(), findAny(): 이들 연산자는 스트림에서 첫 번째 요소 또는 어떤 요소를 찾는 데 사용됩니다. 이들은 Optional 객체를 반환합니다.[CODE_BLOCK_3]이 외에도 다른 최종 연산자들이 있습니다. 각 연산자가 반환하는 값의 유형은 해당 연산자의 동작에 따라 달라집니다. 일부 연산자는 Optional을 반환하며, 일부는 특정 유형의 객체를 반환합니다. 이는 연산이 실패하거나 결과가 없을 경우를 처리하기 위한 것입니다.

Conversations.Answer: 맞습니다, JPA를 사용할 때 Entity의 생성자에서 ID에 관한 생성자를 만들어 주지 않아도 됩니다. JPA에서는 Entity의 ID 값을 관리하는 방식과 객체 생성 방식 때문에 해당 생성자를 만들 필요가 없습니다.JPA에서 Entity의 ID 값을 관리하는 방식은 크게 두 가지로 나뉩니다:자동 생성 (Auto-generated ID): 일반적으로 RDBMS에서 많이 사용되는 방식으로, 데이터베이스가 Entity가 저장될 때 자동으로 ID 값을 생성해주는 방식입니다. 대표적으로 AUTO_INCREMENT와 같은 기능이 이에 해당합니다.수동 생성 (Manual ID assignment): 개발자가 직접 ID 값을 설정하는 방식입니다. 주로 외부 시스템과의 데이터 동기화 등 특수한 경우에 사용됩니다.대부분의 경우, ID 값은 데이터베이스에서 자동으로 생성되기 때문에 생성자에서 ID 값을 명시적으로 받을 필요가 없습니다. JPA는 Entity가 영속성 컨텍스트에 추가될 때 ID 값을 확인하고 적절한 방식으로 설정해주기 때문입니다.Entity 클래스는 보통 기본 생성자를 만들어주는 것이 권장됩니다. 이렇게 기본 생성자를 만들어두면 JPA가 객체를 생성하고 초기화할 때 사용하게 됩니다. 만약 개발자가 특정 생성자를 정의하고 있는데 기본 생성자가 없다면 JPA가 Entity를 올바르게 생성할 수 없을 수 있습니다.예를 들어, JPA가 기본 생성자를 찾지 못해 오류가 발생하는 상황:[CODE_BLOCK_0]이 경우, JPA는 기본 생성자를 찾을 수 없기 때문에 오류가 발생할 수 있습니다. 따라서 기본 생성자를 추가하는 것이 좋습니다:[CODE_BLOCK_1]결론적으로, JPA에서 ID 값을 가져오는 경우 Entity의 생성자에 ID에 관한 매개변수를 추가할 필요는 없습니다. JPA가 올바른 방식으로 ID 값을 설정하고 객체를 생성하도록 기본 생성자를 제공하는 것이 중요합니다.

Conversations.Prompt: how can I create muliple dataframes in python from one dataframe group by a date column?
Conversations.Answer: To create multiple DataFrames in Python from one DataFrame by grouping it based on a date column, you can use the groupby() function from the pandas library. Here's an example of how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the groupby() function is used to group the DataFrame df by the 'date' column. The pd.Grouper() function is used to specify the frequency of grouping, in this case, 'D' for daily grouping. You can adjust the frequency based on your specific requirements, such as 'M' for monthly grouping or 'Y' for yearly grouping.Inside the loop, a new DataFrame named new_df is created for each group using the pd.DataFrame() constructor. You can perform any additional operations or analysis on each new DataFrame as needed.Note that the above example assumes you have a pandas DataFrame named 'df' with a column named 'date' containing datetime values. Adjust the code accordingly if your DataFrame or column names differ.

ListOfCode.Content:
import pandas as pd

# Assuming you have a DataFrame named 'df' with a 'date' column

# Convert the 'date' column to datetime type if it's not already
df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['date'])

# Group the DataFrame by the 'date' column
grouped = df.groupby(pd.Grouper(key='date', freq='D'))

# Iterate over the groups and create individual DataFrames
for group_name, group_data in grouped:
    # 'group_name' is the date value
    # 'group_data' is the corresponding data for that date
    
    # Create a new DataFrame for each group
    new_df = pd.DataFrame(group_data)
    
    # Perform any additional operations or analysis on the new DataFrame
    
    # Print the new DataFrame for demonstration purposes
    print(f"DataFrame for {group_name}:")
    print(new_df)

The 'date' column contains date values, and the 'value' column contains some arbitrary values.The code converts the 'date' column to datetime type using pd.to_datetime() to ensure proper grouping.Then, the DataFrame is grouped by the 'date' column using groupby(pd.Grouper(key='date', freq='D')), specifying daily ('D') frequency.Inside the loop, a new DataFrame named new_df is created for each group using the pd.DataFrame() constructor. In this case, it contains all the rows corresponding to each date.Finally, the code prints each new DataFrame, displaying the data grouped by date for demonstration purposes.

ListOfCode.Content:
import pandas as pd

# Sample DataFrame
data = {'date': ['2023-06-01', '2023-06-01', '2023-06-02', '2023-06-02', '2023-06-03'],
        'value': [10, 20, 30, 40, 50]}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Convert the 'date' column to datetime type
df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['date'])

# Group the DataFrame by the 'date' column
grouped = df.groupby(pd.Grouper(key='date', freq='D'))

# Iterate over the groups and create individual DataFrames
for group_name, group_data in grouped:
    # Create a new DataFrame for each group
    new_df = pd.DataFrame(group_data)
    
    # Perform any additional operations or analysis on the new DataFrame
    
    # Print the new DataFrame for demonstration purposes
    print(f"DataFrame for {group_name}:")
    print(new_df)
    print()

Null characters are not allowed in string literals because they indicate the end of a string in C-style strings.To handle this error, you can use one of the following approaches:Remove or replace the null character: If the null character is not necessary for your string, you can remove it or replace it with another character.[CODE_BLOCK_0]Here, the replace() method is used to remove the null character from the string.Use a byte string (b-string) or raw string: If you need to work with strings that contain null characters, you can use byte strings or raw strings.[CODE_BLOCK_1]Byte strings are denoted by the b prefix, and they allow null characters in the string. Raw strings are denoted by the r prefix, and they treat backslashes as literal characters, so you can include null characters without any issue.Store the string in a file or database: If you need to preserve the null character within a larger dataset, you can store the string in a file or a database instead of a string literal.[CODE_BLOCK_2]By storing the string in a file, you can retain the null character without encountering the error.Choose the approach that best suits your requirements and the nature of the string containing the null character.

Conversations.Prompt: My codebase has a lot of old Go code which uses camel case file names like `tlsConfigHelper.go`. I'd like for all of these files to be renamed to use snake case like `tls_config_helper.go`. Can you write a bash script which will do this?
Conversations.Answer: Certainly! Here's a bash script that can help you rename the Go files from camel case to snake case:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Make sure to replace /path/to/your/codebase with the actual path to your codebase's root folder.Here's how the script works:It changes the current directory to your codebase root folder.It uses the find command to search for all Go files with camel case names.The resulting file paths are filtered using grep to exclude files that don't have a lowercase followed by an uppercase letter in their paths.For each file, it extracts the directory and base name.It converts the camel case base name to snake case using sed and tr.It constructs the new file name by appending the snake case base name to the original directory path.It renames the file using the mv command.Finally, it prints a message indicating the file has been renamed.Please be cautious when running scripts that modify your codebase, and consider making a backup or using version control before executing this script.

ListOfCode.Content:
#!/bin/bash

# Change directory to your codebase root folder
cd /path/to/your/codebase

# Find all Go files with camel case names
files=$(find . -type f -name "*.go" | grep -P '.*\/[a-z]+[A-Z]+.*')

# Loop through each file and rename it
for file in $files; do
  # Get the file's directory and base name
  dir=$(dirname "$file")
  base=$(basename "$file")

  # Convert camel case to snake case
  snake_case=$(echo "$base" | sed -E 's/([^A-Z])([A-Z])/\1_\2/g' | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')

  # Construct the new file name
  new_name="$dir/$(dirname "$base")_$snake_case"

  # Rename the file
  mv "$file" "$new_name"

  echo "Renamed $file to $new_name"
done

#!/usr/bin/env python3

import os
import re
import subprocess

def camel_to_snake(name):
    """Converts a camel case string to snake case."""
    result = ""
    for i, char in enumerate(name):
        if char.isupper() and (i == 0 or (i > 0 and name[i-1].islower())):
            result += char.lower()
        elif char.isupper() and i > 0:
            result += "_" + char.lower()
        else:
            result += char.lower()
    return result

def git_mv(old_path, new_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv'."""
    subprocess.run(['git', 'mv', old_path, new_path])

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements with mockgen command
        pattern = r'//go:generate\s+mockgen\s+.*-destination\s+(\S+)\s*'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                old_path = match
                new_path = camel_to_snake(match)
                updated_content = content.replace(old_path, new_path)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

def main():
    # Change directory to your codebase root folder
    os.chdir(os.path.join(os.environ['HOME'], 'src/temporalio/temporal'))

    # Loop through each file in the directory and its subdirectories
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk('.'):
        for file in files:
            if file.endswith('.go'):
                old_path = os.path.join(root, file)
                new_name = camel_to_snake(file[:-3]) + '.go'
                new_path = os.path.join(root, new_name)

                # Rename the file using 'git mv'
                git_mv(old_path, new_path)
                print(f"Renamed {old_path} to {new_path}")

                # Update go:generate statements in the file
                update_generate_statements(new_path)
                print(f"Updated go:generate statements in {new_path}")

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

#!/usr/bin/env python3

import os
import re
import subprocess

def camel_to_snake(name):
    """Converts a camel case string to snake case."""
    name = name.replace("nDC", "ndc")

    result = ""
    prev_char = ""
    for char in name:
        if char.isupper() and prev_char.islower():
            result += "_" + char.lower()
        else:
            result += char.lower()
        prev_char = char
    return result

def git_mv(old_path, new_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv'."""
    subprocess.run(['git', 'mv', old_path, new_path])

def rename_file(old_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv' and updates go:generate statements."""
    base_name = os.path.basename(old_path)
    new_name = None

    if base_name.endswith("Test.go"):
        prefix = base_name[:-len("Test.go")]
        new_name = "test_" + camel_to_snake(prefix) + ".go"
    else:
        new_name = camel_to_snake(base_name)

    new_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(old_path), new_name)
    git_mv(old_path, new_path)
    print(f"Renamed {old_path} to {new_path}")

    update_generate_statements(new_path)
    print(f"Updated go:generate statements in {new_path}")

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements with mockgen command
        pattern = r'//go:generate\s+mockgen\s+.*-destination\s+(\S+)\s*'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                old_path = match
                new_path = camel_to_snake(match)
                updated_content = content.replace(old_path, new_path)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

def main():
    # Change directory to your codebase root folder
    os.chdir(os.path.join(os.environ['HOME'], 'src/temporalio/temporal'))

    # Loop through each file in the directory and its subdirectories
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk('.'):
        for file in files:
            if file.endswith('.go'):
                file_path = os.path.join(root, file)
                rename_file(file_path)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements
        pattern = r'(?m)^//go:generate\s+(.*)$'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                generate_line = match
                updated_line = generate_line

                # Find Go source code file names on the line
                file_names = re.findall(r'\b(\w+\.go)\b', generate_line)
                if file_names:
                    for old_name in file_names:
                        new_name = camel_to_snake(old_name)
                        updated_line = updated_line.replace(old_name, new_name)

                # Replace the go:generate line with the updated one
                updated_content = content.replace(generate_line, updated_line)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

import os

import tempfile
import unittest
from script import camel_to_snake, rename_file, update_generate_statements

class ScriptTest(unittest.TestCase):
    def setUp(self):
        self.test_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp()

    def tearDown(self):
        shutil.rmtree(self.test_dir)

    def test_camel_to_snake(self):
        self.assertEqual(camel_to_snake("camelCase"), "camel_case")
        self.assertEqual(camel_to_snake("dcRedirectionPolicy_mock.go"), "dc_redirection_policy_mock.go")
        self.assertEqual(camel_to_snake("nDCHistoryResender_mock.go"), "ndc_historyresender_mock.go")

    def test_rename_file(self):
        # Create a dummy Go file
        file_path = os.path.join(self.test_dir, "testFile.go")
        with open(file_path, "w") as file:
            file.write("//go:generate mockgen -source TestFile.go -destination TestFile_mock.go")

        # Rename the file
        rename_file(file_path)

        # Check if the file is renamed
        self.assertFalse(os.path.exists(file_path))
        self.assertTrue(os.path.exists(os.path.join(self.test_dir, "test_file.go")))

        # Check if go:generate statement is updated
        with open(os.path.join(self.test_dir, "test_file.go"), "r") as file:
            content = file.read()
            self.assertIn("-source test_file.go -destination test_file_mock.go", content)

    def test_update_generate_statements(self):
        # Create a dummy Go file
        file_path = os.path.join(self.test_dir, "testFile.go")
        with open(file_path, "w") as file:
            file.write("//go:generate mockgen -source TestFile.go -destination TestFile_mock.go")

        # Update go:generate statements
        update_generate_statements(file_path)

        # Check if go:generate statement is updated
        with open(file_path, "r") as file:
            content = file.read()
            self.assertIn("-source test_file.go -destination test_file_mock.go", content)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    unittest.main()

Here's one way to accomplish this in GitHub Actions:Iterate over each label on the PR.For each label, check if it starts with deploy:.If it does, extract the environment name.Here's a sample workflow that demonstrates this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Few things to note:This uses the jq command-line JSON processor to manipulate the JSON output. ListOfCode.Content:
name: Extract Environment from PR Label

on:
  pull_request:
    types: [labeled]

jobs:
  extract-env:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Check for deploy label and extract environment
        run: |
          # Initialize env as empty
          env_name=""

          # Convert JSON labels to newline-separated list
          labels_list=$(echo '${{ toJSON(github.event.pull_request.labels.*.name) }}' | jq -r '.[]')

          for label in $labels_list; do
            # Check if label starts with 'deploy:'
            if [[ $label == deploy:* ]]; then
              env_name=${label#deploy: }
              echo "Found deploy label for environment: $env_name"
              echo "ENV_NAME=$env_name" >> $GITHUB_ENV
              break
            fi
          done
          
          if [ -z "$env_name" ]; then
            echo "No deploy label found."
          fi

      - name: Use environment name
        run: |
          if [ -n "$ENV_NAME" ]; then
            echo "Deploying to environment: $ENV_NAME"
            # Place your deployment steps or logic here
          fi

Conversations.Answer: このコードでは、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドでファイルの変更を監視しており、変更があるとhandleLoadメソッドを呼び出しています。しかし、handleWatchFileChangesメソッド内でhandleLoadメソッドを呼び出す際に、引数としてfilePathしか渡していません。修正するには、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドでhandleLoadメソッドを呼び出す際に、適切な引数で呼び出す必要があります。具体的には、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドの定義を以下のように修正します：[CODE_BLOCK_0]handleWatchFileChangesメソッドの呼び出し元で、handleGetFileEncodingメソッドを使用してencodingを取得し、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドに渡す必要があります。具体的には、handleMainメソッドの以下の部分を修正します：[CODE_BLOCK_1]これにより、handleLoadメソッドが正しい引数で呼び出され、不要な追加のリロードとコンソールログが発生しなくなるはずです。

handleWatchFileChangesメソッド内でファイルの変更を監視する際に、イベントハンドラーが2回呼び出されることが原因です。これは、fs.watchメソッドが変更イベント(change)が発生した場合に複数回呼び出されることがあるためです。この問題を解決するには、handleWatchFileChangesメソッド内で最初の変更イベントが発生した時点でイベントハンドラーを一時的に無効化し、2回目以降の呼び出しを無視する必要があります。以下は修正例です：[CODE_BLOCK_0]上記の修正では、最初の変更イベントが発生した後、1秒間の間は監視フラグが無効化されます。その間に発生する変更イベントは無視されます。1秒後に監視フラグが再度有効化されるため、その後の変更イベントが再び処理されるようになります。この修正により、1回のファイル変更に対して1回のコンソールログと1回のリロードが行われるはずです。必要に応じて、無視する時間間隔を調整してください。

Conversations.Prompt:
`fs.watchメソッドが変更イベント(change)が発生した場合に複数回呼び出されることがあるためです。`
何故ですか???
Conversations.Answer: fs.watchメソッドは、ファイルシステムの変更を監視するための非常に低レベルなメソッドです。しかし、その振る舞いはプラットフォームに依存するため、正確な動作が一貫していません。特に、一部のオペレーティングシステムでは、複数の変更イベントが発生することがあります。具体的には、ファイルの変更が発生すると、fs.watchメソッドは複数回のイベントを発火することがあります。これは、変更の種類やファイルシステムの実装によるものです。例えば、一度のファイル変更が内部的に複数のイベントとして処理される場合があります。そのため、ファイルの変更を監視する際には、複数回のイベントが発生する可能性に対処する必要があります。先ほど提案した修正では、最初の変更イベントに対してのみ処理を行い、その後のイベントを一時的に無視する方法を採用しています。ただし、これらの問題はfs.watchメソッド自体の仕様や実装に関連しており、完全に制御することは難しいです。そのため、ファイルの変更を正確に検知する必要がある場合は、より高度な方法やサードパーティライブラリを検討することをおすすめします。たとえば、chokidarやnode-watchなどのモジュールがあります。これらのモジュールは、fs.watchよりも信頼性が高く、正確な変更検知が可能です。

Conversations.Prompt: what is the difference between u"abc" and U"abc" in Python?
Conversations.Answer: In Python, the "u" and "U" prefixes before a string literal are used to indicate Unicode string literals. However, in Python 3, the "u" prefix is not necessary as all string literals are Unicode by default.In Python 2, the "u" prefix is used to create a Unicode string literal, while the "U" prefix is used to create a Unicode string literal that is treated as a raw string. A raw string treats backslashes as literal characters rather than escape characters. Here's an example to illustrate the difference:[CODE_BLOCK_0]However, in Python 3, all string literals are Unicode by default, and the "U" prefix is no longer recognized. You can simply use a regular string literal to represent Unicode strings:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In summary, the "u" prefix was used in Python 2 to indicate a Unicode string literal, while the "U" prefix was used to indicate a raw Unicode string literal. In Python 3, the "u" prefix is no longer necessary, and all string literals are Unicode by default.

ListOfCode.Content:
# Python 2
u_string = u"abc"  # Unicode string
U_string = U"abc"  # Raw Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: abc
print(U_string)  # Output: abc

# Backslash is treated as an escape character
u_string = u"\n"  # Unicode string
U_string = U"\n"  # Raw Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: (newline character)
print(U_string)  # Output: \n (literal backslash followed by 'n')

# Python 3
u_string = "abc"  # Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: abc

# Backslash is treated as an escape character
u_string = "\n"  # Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: (newline character)

This function/method should be the one that creates new instances of your main classes and calls any necessary startup methods.For instance, you could create a new initGame function in your game.js file:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Then, in your application's main entry point file (which might be a different JavaScript file that gets loaded in your HTML), you'd call this initGame function to start the game.
